reviewText: A tiny bit of it is unpolished but if you can see past that, you will find an amazingly fun and addictive game. It's like god of war mixed with a really fun RPG that allows you to pick your upgrades from 3 trees (Stealth, Fighter, Mage) and allows you to mix the trees up, the only limit is the number of points you have to spend and the level requirement for that tier, as well as the occassional pre-requisite to have an upgrade from an earlier tier to be in your repitoire before you can unlock a later tier upgrade in that tree. There is a main storyline, but the side quests are a blast and are littered throughout each map. You'll want to hit up the DLC content around level 9 or 10 due to the gear that drops being for level 1 through 18. The enemies are gorgeous to look at while you come up with awesome new combos or ways to kill them, and the view of your surroundings is beautiful in most levels. One of the most beautiful places to visit are the caverns with the all the glowing effects and magical sprites floating about, really nice to look at.  Don't forget to check out the arena in the desert and battle your way to new gear and other rewards. So many things to do and see in this game, it will keep you enthralled for a good 50 hours at least. Add in a couple of playthroughs to explore each area fully and see the different reactions to another race choice and you have well over 100 hours of hard core RPG/action to fall in love with. Each enemy is crafted with such tiny details, my favorite is the one with the wood mask facade for a face that opens up to reveal some really sharp and evil looking teeth and glowing eyes atop a gaping mouth. So many details in the architecture make each area you visit a wonder to behold as you walk around just soaking in the view that the extremely talented artists rendered. I really wish there were more games like this. Just like with the Elder Scrolls and Fallout worlds, i could spend months in here and never feel bored.

reviewText:
Really a shame what happened with the devs, this is an extremely good ARPG with only some small issues - narrow field of view and a crafting system that takes a hot second to get used to.

That being said, the game itself has at least 70-80 hours of content outside of DLCs if you explore, and the achievements definitely incentivize exploring. You can switch up your character at will when you find better loot - and better loot you will find - in a ton of different ways, with all kinds of different hybrid playstyles being viable and fun alternatives to ther norm.

The takedowns in Reckoning mode are flashy, the executions from stealth are super satisfying... And for 6$ every other week it's embarrassing not to own a game with this much quality content by now.

reviewText: So far, I've only played about 2-3hrs~ worth, but I can guarantee that this is an amazing game. It is a more robust 'Fable-esque' RPG with MMO canon combined with it. I also didn't get the DLC, but I'm sure that it's just as good as the base-game. Plus, I managed to make a character look like Jennifer Lawrence, 10/10.

reviewText:
I am still trying to figure out why I hadn't heard of this game. Upon further study, I realize it's because I was too busy with Skyrim... However, this game is on-par with skyrim when it comes to playability and fun and I'm sad I missed it. I would have payed full price for it. Ended up getting it during the 2014 winter sale.

The visual style and combat is nothing like skyrim. In my opinion, the combat in skyrim is more fun only because you can make it as challenging as you want. People say this game is easy, and they're not lying. If you're looking for a harder experience start out pure mage. If the combat was harder, it would far surpass skyrims system. The flow of it is very fun and worth it even despite it's easiness, which should say alot about it.

The quests are fun and rewarding, and the loot/equipment system is more akin to Diablo than Elder Scrolls. Some people will like that, and some people won't. I love it. The alchemy and blacksmithing system is awesome, and it gives you a reason to go around collecting raegents and tools. In fact, I can't think of an RPG Alchemy system that did it more right. I'd say they even have the Witcher beat when it comes to that.

All in all, highly recommended if you're a fan of RPGs. I didn't want to spend too much time comparing this game to skyrim and failed heavily, but Elder Scrolls are one of my favorite game series on the planet and this game is right up there. Looking forward to more playtime!
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning delivers exactly what it promises: a pitch-perfect fantasy RPG, with visceral, intuitive gameplay that is easy to pick up, difficult to master, wildly flexible and just plain fun, in a way that has yet to be seen in the genre. The world is accessible and vast, offering genre fans plenty to sink their teeth into. One gets the sense that they are watching an entire world unfold before them, one rich with history and lore and life. Amalur opens itself up to the player in a way that is both familiar and refreshing, then empowers the player to do incredible things. 38 Studios and Big Huge Games have created a world worth saving, and they have given us some pretty damn cool tools with which to get the job done.

reviewText: This is an amazing little gem, it has all of the characteristics of an early Skyrim but it is simple enough to play, I would recommend this game because of the playability which is second to none.  Its really easy to pick up and you can play to how you prefer to play it in terms of fighting style, there are 3 base classes to choose from, which in turn, each have a complex tree of varying combinations of classes.  The world you play in is a very vibrant one, full of colour and texture.  There is alchemy, blacksmithing, you can upgrade certain weapons and armor and best of all, for all lovers of RPG's, there's plenty of loot.  Money is scarce at first but after a dozens missions or so under your belt and you will see how quickly your money can build up.  You can level up your character, choose as you will because you can always change completely at anytime by visiting Fateweavers who will, for price, reset your levels so that you can rebuild to a different style.

reviewText:
This game is really good. The graphics have that sort of fantasy vibe to it, although it's not really at a good resolution. I'm not sure how you change the resolution either. There doesn't seem to be any graphics options that let you change it. That's very bad. Very very bad. My monitor is a 1680x1050 and it looks a bit washed out with this resolution. I can still play it, but I just wish I could change some of the graphics options.

Edit: Upon further inspection, the only time you can change the graphics options are in the main menu.

The gameplay is pure hack-and-slash fun. Think of games like Darksiders. That is kind of this game (minus the epic areial combos). This game is also a loot-fest. You get new equipment very frequently (if you take the time to explore). All the weapons are really fun to use and have different strengths and weaknesses to them, like the daggers being the fast and low-damage type, hammers which are the slow but hard-hitting type, typical etc. etc.. You also can do numerous special moves that you unlock with each weapon type. You also have this fate weaving ability (forgot what it was called) where you press and hold the triggers (or the keyboard equivalent) to slow down time and kill your enemies faster and impale them to death with large energy spears...Hmm. Yes. Overall, very fun and engaging combat.

The story is alright, it's not cliche, but it's nothing to write home about. You are basically the vitcim of a war, and you have died. Yes, you heard me right. You died. But don't fret, something called the well of life resurrected you. I don't really know anything else because I most likely have forgotten. The voice acting is also quite good. Not Skyrim levels, but still it's not gut wrenchingly bad.

The only thing that I would have had improved is the user interface. The inventory system feels very cluttered and since your items are featured on one page in a sort of list structure, albiet seperated in categories, it's hard to navigate. I wish they would've shown all of your items on the single screen instead of having to scroll down to see which new items you have acquired, or want to equip, etc. Also the camera kind of sucks, it's very close sometimes, and then sometimes it's further away.

Overall, I like this game and would reccommend anyone who likes games like Skyrim or Darksiders to pick this up. Though not at full price.

reviewText: Combat is where Kingdoms of Amalur truly shines.   Other RPGs do present an overall better and complete package in terms of lore, story and characters, such as Dragon Age: Origins (the last true Bioware game), Skyrim (the best of the Elder Scrolls series) and Knights of the Old Republic (one of my personal favorites).  However, combat in these games is something to get through" and "endure."     In Kingdoms of Amular combat is something that is enjoyed in the moment."

reviewText:
Much to my surprise, I'm rather enjoying this game so far (I'm about 2 hours in). First off, I have to point out that this game is heavly focused on combat and less so on story and epic adventures which is why I was surprised as I tend to lead more towards those games.

The combat in this game is very good in fact, its among the best I've come across in an action RPG. This games biggest pro's are the entertaining combat sequences, the rather large selection of spells and abilities and the selection of weapons / armour.

When in comes to the charcters and story, this game is somewhat average, but fortunately the fun you get from the gameplay makes up for this and you tend to forget about the wooden characters and the mediocre main quest. I won't go into to much detail but the game is worth playing if the story is not everything to you.

All in all, I recommend this game to any action RPG fan and if your interest leans more toward gameplay and combat than the main storyline then you won't be dissapointed.

I give this game a 7.5 / 10 - Good.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning delivers exactly what it promises: a pitch-perfect fantasy RPG, with visceral, intuitive gameplay that is easy to pick up, difficult to master, wildly flexible and just plain fun, in a way that has yet to be seen in the genre. The world is accessible and vast, offering genre fans plenty to sink their teeth into. One gets the sense that they are watching an entire world unfold before them, one rich with history and lore and life. Amalur opens itself up to the player in a way that is both familiar and refreshing, then empowers the player to do incredible things. 38 Studios and Big Huge Games have created a world worth saving, and they have given us some pretty damn cool tools with which to get the job done.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is an amazing little gem, it has all of the characteristics of an early Skyrim but it is simple enough to play, I would recommend this game because of the playability which is second to none.  Its really easy to pick up and you can play to how you prefer to play it in terms of fighting style, there are 3 base classes to choose from, which in turn, each have a complex tree of varying combinations of classes.  The world you play in is a very vibrant one, full of colour and texture.  There is alchemy, blacksmithing, you can upgrade certain weapons and armor and best of all, for all lovers of RPG's, there's plenty of loot.  Money is scarce at first but after a dozens missions or so under your belt and you will see how quickly your money can build up.  You can level up your character, choose as you will because you can always change completely at anytime by visiting Fateweavers who will, for price, reset your levels so that you can rebuild to a different style.

reviewText: It's a pretty standard Fantasy Action Game experience - you pick from a couple of Totally Unique Racial Categories, make some basic cosmetic changes (hair, skin tone, etc.) and then you go smash the crap out of things.\n\nCharacter progression is somewhat reminiscent of Torchlight with a bit of The Witcher for good measure.  You can multiclass" between Tough Smashy Style
recommended:
and Explody Magic Style.

The lore is more-or-less your standard fantasy novel business - there's good (not-)elves and bad (not-)elves and the bad (not-)elves are going HAM on your homeland.  Good thing you're a Chosen One and can stand up to those naughty naughty (not-)elves!  Did we mention that you have a Mysterious Past that you have to uncover?  Of course you do.

It's going to be tainted by comparison to Skyrim
hoursPlayed: as they're both Epic Fantasy Smashy Smash games.  Skyrim excels in having a truly open world (much of KOA is pretty much linear - the old invisible fence is full in effect here) and near-limitless modification capacity.  KOA excels at having a much more enjoyable combat system - lots of fancy combos and trick moves.  There's a "rage meter" mechanic that's kind of neat in a silly "Mortal Kombat" way - you charge up your murders and then you go into Super Murder Mode
voteText: where you get
helpfulPercent: of all things
votesHelpful: a quicktime event where you have to mash buttons to Extra Super Duper Murder someone for bonus XP.\n\nIt's silly
votesTotal: even for Epic Fantasy Gaming
votesFunny: but it's probably worth snagging on sale."

reviewText:
What an amazing game! It's so weird it's not mentioned often when talking about RPGs. This game should be in top 3 atleast!

The game is huge, there's tons and tons and tons of things to do. The storylines are fun and easy to follow (even for me, who usually doesn't care about stories too much). I'm sure there's something out there for all of you.

The only downside is that it's abit easy but then again, I'm not a fan of games that get so hard that makes me want to throw my pc out the window.

Would I recommend this? Yes, absolutely. 10/10

The plot is convincing enough.
Classes are fun and versatile.

CONS:
The difficulty should be set to HARD.
You are very overpowered.
Sometimes the game feel a bit unfinished.

My score: 8/10

reviewText:
I will openly admit that I had absolutely no intention originally of ever picking this game up... until it went on sale majorly discounted (Thank you, Steam!) and a friend told me to just give it a shot. I have to say, I rather enjoy it very much and I am kicking myself for not giving it a shot before.

The artstyle for this is what hit me first. It has such a bright and colorful atmosphere while still being able to be dark when it needs to be. I find myself looking around each and every new area I visit rather thuroughly and not being disappointed in the least. The designs of the characters, items and equipment are also very unique and the fact that Todd McFarlane had his hands in it really shows.

It has a story that really draws you in and it has such an ambiguous morality meter that you really feel your impacts on the world. the gameplay is just as fun and addictive as well adding a unique combo and weapon swap ability that just works and the magic use itself is spectacular. It is not without it's faults though as I found the quests themselves rather repetative. Other than that, it is definitely worth the full price that it is. :) 8.5/10
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Great little gem I had never heard anything about. Bought it on a whim and it was worth every dollar. Nothing revolutionary but I love how you can fine tune the combat to your style considering I love being a Jack-of-all-Trades player and often times a player is penalized for it.

The world is large enough that it was occasionally a bother to get from one place to another but for me it adds to the immersion, but not too large that you'll waste all your time wandering it or having to fast travel from one place to the other exclusively.

The writing, quests and options available to you are all well done with relatively few bugs. Only bug I found was a quest where you had to get an item from a character and rather than kill him I stole it, game didn't like that so I killed him, then it didn't count the item in my inventory but I couldn't grab something he didn't have at that point. Slightly annoying but if that's the only issue I had I'll give it two big thumbs up.

reviewText:
Impression after an hour:  Wow, why hadn't I heard about this?  It kidna has a stupid name.  At least, it's not catchy.  Apparently it didnt' sell well enough and the companies involved went under.

Controller friendly, interesting art style, polished, good lore, kinda action combat that seems fun so far.

I got it on sale.  Looking forward to finishing it.

FIVE HOURS: I still like it.  I'll see how much staying power it has, still like the art style and the combat.  Aside from the stupid name, I'm thinking what killed the company is it's not an exceptional game.  It's standard high fantasty, but it's not gritty or enthalling in a way like the Witcher or Dragon Age is.  The writing is a big part of those, this does feel more like FedEx quests.  But I paid about a tenth fo this of what I paid for Dragon Age.  So far I still think I got my money's worth, and it doesn't have the addictive quality of some othe rgames it's still fun so far.

reviewText: Yes, I currently don't have many hours logged on this yet, but on the Xbone I do. Anyways, this game is really under-rated. I say it would give you a good 50+ hours of enjoyable gameplay. I like the combat system and I like the story and quest. I love games that likes to let you explore and this game captures that perfectly. I constantly find myself wandering through caves, forests, and cities. The only con I have with this game is the lack of difficulty. When you hit levle 25-30 every boss become really easy to kill. So by then you should just crank up your difficulty level and keep moving. Of course there are tiny little flaws, but I can't even remember them so they are nothing to worry about. KOA: Reckoning is a playful, exciting, fresh RPG which deserves much more attention.\n\n9.5/10 Sloanster Stars

reviewText:
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a colossal and deep RPG with a beautiful atmosphere.

The world you can explore is huge, even though it is parted into many little regions which are designed rather linear. However, this makes it easier to find every quest and not to miss something important. There are tons of caves, cities, castles and forests  that are enjoyable to explore. Besides, you can fast-travel to any location you have visited so far, which is a great tool.

There are three skilltrees in which you can invest , you do not have to limit your points to one of them. You can mix them up in any way you want to. You will encounter several fateweavers in the game which can reset your skill points for a bit some money, depending on your level. The level cap in this game is 40.

The story itself is pretty cool and presented very well but gets a bit lengthy towards the end, yet the ending itself is spectacular again. There are several moments where you can influence certain outcomes with your decisions.

There is a extremely large number of available side-quests in this game,  I ended up having completed around 300 of them (with both DLC’s). Some of them go with the standard pattern like finding some reagents or killing some mobs while on the other hand there are some pretty big side-quests that bring a little story on their own which are very entertaining to follow.

The game has 3 difficulty-settings and I recommend you to play it on hard since it’s still pretty easy on medium as long as you’re not fighting large groups of enemies, especially towards the end when you got the best kinds of armor and weapons.

There is a variety of different enemies that behave different in battle which leads to entertaining fights. The Gameplay itself is pretty good in my eyes,  especially the combats are very dynamic.

The graphics are quite good for early 2012 and the world is designed with a love for detail. You’ll find many different environments that feel alive. The great music of this game strengthens the atmosphere even more.

On the downside, there are some bugs in this game which will never get fixed because the studio that produced this game went bankrupt. However, most of these bugs just make some quest items being stuck in your inventory after you completed the quest or other minor things that one can oversee.

In Amalur, you can acquire various houses in which you can store your items, you can even earn an own arena and a mining company which gain you money over time.

There are various weapon types with different advantages and downsides which brings some additional diversity.

Regarding the DLC’s, I can greatly recommend you “The Legend of Dead Kel” and “Teeth of Naros”, which both have a great storyline and add another big map part to the already huge map each. However, the “Weapons & Armor Bundle” just adds a bit of loot that falls off quite quick and in my opinion is not worth the money.

All in All, I truly recommend giving Kingdoms of Amalur a try, for it a large and beautiful game with a wonderful atmosphere.



P.S.: Sorry for my bad English, it’s not my native language.

reviewText:
Amazing game, loving the story and tochlight-esqe gameplay. Not overly impressed with the graphics or animations. Seems like the immersion could have been increased alot if the developers did just a few minor tweaks. For instance, switching weapons. In Koa:R, a new weapon will magically appear in your hand. How long would it have taken to animate that?

Enjoying this a TON more than Skyrim. Imagine Skyrim with a better story, less walking, and better combat... That is Koa:R.

Overall a very good game, but a lot of minor mistakes ruin emmersion.

reviewText: KoA: TR is a classic action / RPG in the style of Dungeon Seige III.  As such, its appeal is mostly for fans of the console based RPG who enjoy the simplistic interface and sophisticated button mashing combat.  I come strictly from the PC world so I tend to prefer things like Skyrim, Baldur's Gate, and the like.  However this game managed to keep my attention because of its charm" and great combat.\n\nI assume that you are familiar with the basics of an ARPG title
date: so I'll skip right to the pros:\n> The world is absolutely huge.  I have 40 hours logged so far and have completed about half the game in terms of exploring the map.\n> The number of quests and side quests is equally enormous.  Given this
recommended: the means for managing them all works quite well... any quest can be designated "primary" and tracked easily through the kingdom.  Secondary quests appear only on the detailed map which shows the immediate area.\n> The voice acting is excellent
hoursPlayed: and ALL NPC dialog is spoken.  I recognized one of the voice actors from Skyrim!  I wouldn't be surprised if there are others from the school of Bethesda.\n>  The combat
voteText: which is the meat and potatoes of the game really
helpfulPercent:
is fantastic.  This is the primary reason to play this game.  The controls are easy to learn (I recommend an XBOX controller) and the unlocks as you progress are interesting and powerful.
> Although there are basic classes (ranged/mage/tank) the level of customization available allows you to combine classes in interesting ways or focus on a specific branch within the class.
> Crafting is available (create gems/blacksmithing/alchemy)... and exploring any one of those paths yeilds GREAT rewards mid-late game.
> The pacing is excellent
votesHelpful: and largely under your control.\n> AWESOME support for 3D Vision... you will want to patch the game using helixmods.  Google it.\n> Great weapon effects
votesTotal: such as flame
votesFunny: electricity
commentsCount: ice etc.\n> The story is interesting.\n> The camera is generally well managed by the game
column16:
particularly in combat.
> It is possible to completely "respec" your character at any time!

And the CONS:
> Graphically the game reminds me of world of warcraft... rather cartoonish.  Not necessarily a deal killer but I prefer a more realistic look.
> The character animations are limited
column17: in particular when speaking dialog.  You will see the same animations repeated hundreds of times
column18: to the point where you begin to notice them... a bit distracting.\n> Occasionally there are some wild camera glitches.\n> The difficulty can be uneven
column19: especially early in the game.  You will be sailing along beating up baddies with abandon and then be unable to complete a boss fight without reducing the difficulty.  That seems to be less of a problem by mid-game if you have been managing your build well.\n> The loot drops are generally not that interesting... mostly junk
column20:
at least by mid-game... although by that time you have a specific build in mind and you are looking for specific loot.  I find that merchants are a better source of loot than drops.

Overall I heartily recommend this game
9/10 (if you have 3d Vision

reviewText: Pretty good, but lacks its own identity (feels like Everquest + Fable, and a dozen other rpgs at once), and suffers from a lot of what makes modern RPGs (even many FPS) suck; being artificially extended with pointless busywork.\n\n90% Sidequests for Deliver this to-, Kill 8 of-,.. Hey you're supposed to be a warrior on an important mission to save the world
date: but can you go fetch my <mundane object>?"\n\nIt's certainly not this game's fault. They ALL do that these days because it's an incredibly easy way to flesh out a game. Leveling via uninpired fetch quests isn't so bad in an MMORPG
recommended: but its dull as hell in single player games. I'm not anti-sidequest by any means
hoursPlayed: its just that they're a whole lot more common and less creative than they used to be.\n\nI'd still recommend it for the $5 I paid

reviewText: Alright, well, here we go, I bought this game under the impression it was open world, and had RPG elements, which it did have on both accounts, HOWEVER, After playing for 20 hours I came to a realization, this game is monotonous, it feels like ive been doing the same side quest 50 TIMES, the main story itself was intriguing, and combat is fairly fluid and dynamic, the class system in this game is different to say the least.\nTo summarize, I came away from this game the same way I came away from Skyrim, its alot of fun, until you do everything, the choices you make have no real consequence, and the world seems HUGE on the map, but the reality is, its just large open (or semi-closed) spaces with the same brands of monsters scattered throughout the world at large, there is a backstory, but your so caught up in everything, you dont see it, I recomend this game when its onsale (for like 10$) but otherwise 7/10

reviewText: The game is actually pretty great and I would love to recommend it but it also managed to provide me with some of the most frustrating gaming experiences I've ever had, enough for me to just uninstall it after 30 hours of play time.  There are several bugs in the game that there are no fixes for and which get you stuck, permanently.  So if you didn't make a separate save (not auto-save) then you basically have to start over.  The first time it happened I had a save from like 10 hours previous, very frustrating but I kept playing.  Then it happened again on another quest.  It just blows my mind that the developers don't even acknowledge it, let alone try to issue a patch for it.

reviewText: Just like the description of the game, it's litterally Salvatore, McFarlane and Rolston meshed into one. This game is freaking rad. reviewText:
I'm hesitant to recommend this game because I didn't love it, but for some reason I kept playing it until the end.  I found myself speeding through some of the more boring bits of the game just to see the main storyline through to completion, but honestly, the main story leaves much to be desired.  The world is huge and feels very complete, but unfortunately much of this is lost if you--like me--can't quite cross the threshold into obsession with exploring the world.

The gameplay is fairly fun and varied for an action RPG, but the skill progression for the sorcery tree is VERY unbalanced.  You'll spend the first third of the game abusing the same couple of abilities over and over again, feeling somewhat underpowered and dependent on your physical weapon to fill in the damage gaps.  It starts to balance out a bit in the middle of the sorcery tree, but then the scales are tipped ridiculously upon reaching the highest tier.  The Meteor ability is capable of wiping out an entire group of enemies, and while it does have a long cooldown, it is always ready by the time you reach the next group and doesn't consume enough mana to slow you down.  Speaking of mana, itemization was a bit frustrating and seemed too random.  I finished the game with a staff bought from a vendor, but then again, I was just destroying armies of fools with giant meteors summoned from the depths of space, so who needs a nice staff?

One of the things that continued to irritate me in this game is the sound.  I'm not sure if they didn't have the budget for a good sound team or if they hired amateurs, but the sounds in this game feel completely wrong.  One example is the sound they used for a shattering clay jar.  It doesn't feel like part of the environment, but instead a flat sound file played slightly out of sync with the action.  There are many other examples of terrible sounds throughout the game.  The music was occasionally decent, but for the most part it was forgettable.

The graphics in this game were nice enough, and the art style felt consistent and well-done.  Framerate was never an issue on my aging machine--even with settings on max--so clearly the core tech team behind the engine knew what they were doing.

All of my complaints aside, I still found myself coming back to this game day after day to see what was around the next bend.  Upon completion, I almost felt as if I could do more exploring or wrap up some of those faction quests I left unfinished...but, I have better games to play.  If you like MMO-style gameplay and want to get lost in a big, lonely world for hours on end, give Kingdoms of Amalur a shot.  However, if you--like me--find yourself with less and less time to play games these days, you may not get as much out of this game as you put into it.

reviewText:
Immerse yourself in an all-new massive universe from the minds of bestselling author R.A. Salvatore, Spawn creator Todd McFarlane, and Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion lead designer Ken Rolston. Choose your path and battle through a sprawling world featuring intense, responsive, and customizable RPG combat.

'It may lack the precision of, say Witcher 2's combat, but it makes for a style that can be picked up in seconds, customised to your own particular style of play and crowned with impressive arcade-style finishes... Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a triumph that makes the prospect of a future MMO based on the same world and engine all the more enticing.'

'While not the first game to be called a hybrid of action and RPG, it certainly is the hallmark of the former, with the robust content that's generally expected of the latter. If you were hoping to be connected to the characters like you did in some of R.A. Salvatore's great fantasy novels, you will undoubtedly be disappointed. But Amalur is still a beautiful and immense world with plenty of secrets to discover and combat that is ceaselessly satisfying.'

'Reckoning is an absolutely engaging fantasy experience where the main story and nearly every side quest winds around the idea that you're character is not just disrupting - but improving - the fate of the world.'

'No matter what you're looking for, whether it be amazing gameplay, immersive storytelling or perhaps a riveting new world to explore as you fully customize and re-customize your character at will, Reckoning has it all.'

'This game is fiendishly addictive, it displays exceptional pacing and once you start playing, it's very difficult to stop. The constant flow of quests, the infinite looting, the polished skill tree with the dozens of combinations, the functional interface, its superb battle sequences and the enormous world that challenges you to explore, compose a game worth investing, as you will need more than 100 hours to see everything.'

reviewText:
This game is:

An rpg
That plays like Dragon Age: Origins
That also plays like an MMO
With the combat style of Dragon Age: 2.

I'll explain. If you've ever played an MMO before, you'll know that there's a rotation to your skills/abilities. This game offers up three sorts of abilities - melee, ranged, and magic. The game allows you cross-abilities and encourages it. The UI is set up like a typical MMO sort. The controls aren't difficult to grasp.

You move as though you were in an action game. Think Kingdom Hearts if you've ever played that. Or Devil May Cry.

This game came out about the same time as Skyrim. It was overlooked because of this, and subsequently the developers went out of business.

This is a tragedy. The game has the same open world feel as Skyrim, and allows you to fast travel to places you've been before. The looting system is much the same, only it allows for more.

For instance, you get the inventory is full instead of slowing down.

For another, within your inventory are bags. Each bag is for a crafting. Alchemy, sagecrafting (jewelcrafting), and blacksmithing. The components for all are placed within these bags, and not in your actual inventory. So you can stock up as much as you like on them all.

You're able to purchase a house, expand it, and have your own shared storage within it.

The scenery is gorgeous, the characters are pretty amusing, and while the character customization is sparse, you're allowed to be something other than friggin' human.

The plot has an absolutely fascinating premise, and how many games can you play that starts you off in a dumping ground for corpses?

It also touches a LOT on fae mythology. Brownies, trolls, sprites, etc. The elves are particularly badass in this game rather than being a bunch of pretentious snots or a downtrodden race.

The downside to this game is that there won't be any sequels coming to it due to the company going out of business.

reviewText:
This game surprised me.  I read some reveiws that said it was surprisingly good but it still caught me off guard.  I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I am.  It's a pleasant feeling to be surprised these days by a game that seemed to be so resoundingly denounced on release.  I highly recommend playing it, even with all its' flaws, because it's fun and familiar.

Let's get the bad out of the way:
-The first 30 minutes.  It's awkward to control without tweaking because it was absolutely designed to be used with a controller.  If you have one, I recommend using it.  If not, tinker with sensitivity and hotkeys to make it more playable.  The defacto tutorial level is unimpressive, slightly confusing, and rather buggy.  It takes you through each class and weapon type but you don't have to commit just yet.  At this point it seems to be super linear, on rails type of game but push through to the first village and it opens up.
-The camera.  It takes getting used to.  The third person perspective is unfortunate.  While I generally play in third person, not having the option to move the camera is frustrating at times.  This is one of the areas where it's design for consoles is very evident.
-Vanilla.  This isn't really a negative or a positive.  It's what you expect from a game like this.  Some fetch quests, some kill quests, some steal quests, a few factions and schools to join, and the RPG trinity of classes.  Even with some multiclassing, it's still an expected experience class wise.

The Good:
-Rich lore.  If you didn't know, it is written by RA Salvatore and it shows.  Some of the stories feel familiar if you are a fan of his books.  One of the first questlines, The House of Ballads, is very interesting and they continue in the vein throughout.
-Tons of side quests.  You can get lost in sidequests for a few hours with each new area and those discovered in the wild.
-Combat seems simple on the surface (and can remain so if you desire) but with multiclassing can become dynamic and engaging.
-Crafting! I generally only craft because I have to but this system makes it easy.  It is not particularly deep or impressive in it's installation but it is perfect for players like me who don't generally dump a ton of time into it.  I like that you can craft usable items at any point no matter the skill level.  Strength of weapons or armor are based on components used and NOT player skill.  A small but important distiction.

This game is everything you expect from an open world RPG in the Elder Scrolls vein.  Why would that be a bad thing?  Just because it has been done before doesn't mean it can't be done again and done well.  Pick it up and have fun with it, I know I have.

reviewText:
The RPG format is one where you have fairly clear expectations.  Despite this, most of them get it wrong.  But KOA Reckoning is the first one I've found in a long time that has actually had me telling myself I needed to go to bed (and then ignored my own advice).

The storyline is rich, which a lot of developers forget is important when you're supposed to be *playing* a role in a virtual world, and the gameplay is fun and flexible.  As much as I love games like The Witcher, the user interface and controls can be awkward and clumsy; this game overcomes those problems and is genuinely enjoyable from start to finish - where you'll actually *want* to spend dozens of hours off on lore-related side quests instead of begrudgingly doing them out of necessity.

Overall one of the best RPGs that I've ever played.  I haven't checked out the DLC yet, but it's definitely something I'll be doing and not just considering.

reviewText:
Immerse yourself in an all-new massive universe from the minds of bestselling author R.A. Salvatore, Spawn creator Todd McFarlane, and Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion lead designer Ken Rolston. Choose your path and battle through a sprawling world featuring intense, responsive, and customizable RPG combat.

'It may lack the precision of, say Witcher 2's combat, but it makes for a style that can be picked up in seconds, customised to your own particular style of play and crowned with impressive arcade-style finishes... Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a triumph that makes the prospect of a future MMO based on the same world and engine all the more enticing.'

'While not the first game to be called a hybrid of action and RPG, it certainly is the hallmark of the former, with the robust content that's generally expected of the latter. If you were hoping to be connected to the characters like you did in some of R.A. Salvatore's great fantasy novels, you will undoubtedly be disappointed. But Amalur is still a beautiful and immense world with plenty of secrets to discover and combat that is ceaselessly satisfying.'

'Reckoning is an absolutely engaging fantasy experience where the main story and nearly every side quest winds around the idea that you're character is not just disrupting - but improving - the fate of the world.'

'No matter what you're looking for, whether it be amazing gameplay, immersive storytelling or perhaps a riveting new world to explore as you fully customize and re-customize your character at will, Reckoning has it all.'

'This game is fiendishly addictive, it displays exceptional pacing and once you start playing, it's very difficult to stop. The constant flow of quests, the infinite looting, the polished skill tree with the dozens of combinations, the functional interface, its superb battle sequences and the enormous world that challenges you to explore, compose a game worth investing, as you will need more than 100 hours to see everything.'

reviewText:
This game is:

An rpg
That plays like Dragon Age: Origins
That also plays like an MMO
With the combat style of Dragon Age: 2.

I'll explain. If you've ever played an MMO before, you'll know that there's a rotation to your skills/abilities. This game offers up three sorts of abilities - melee, ranged, and magic. The game allows you cross-abilities and encourages it. The UI is set up like a typical MMO sort. The controls aren't difficult to grasp.

You move as though you were in an action game. Think Kingdom Hearts if you've ever played that. Or Devil May Cry.

This game came out about the same time as Skyrim. It was overlooked because of this, and subsequently the developers went out of business.

This is a tragedy. The game has the same open world feel as Skyrim, and allows you to fast travel to places you've been before. The looting system is much the same, only it allows for more.

For instance, you get the inventory is full instead of slowing down.

For another, within your inventory are bags. Each bag is for a crafting. Alchemy, sagecrafting (jewelcrafting), and blacksmithing. The components for all are placed within these bags, and not in your actual inventory. So you can stock up as much as you like on them all.

You're able to purchase a house, expand it, and have your own shared storage within it.

The scenery is gorgeous, the characters are pretty amusing, and while the character customization is sparse, you're allowed to be something other than friggin' human.

The plot has an absolutely fascinating premise, and how many games can you play that starts you off in a dumping ground for corpses?

It also touches a LOT on fae mythology. Brownies, trolls, sprites, etc. The elves are particularly badass in this game rather than being a bunch of pretentious snots or a downtrodden race.

The downside to this game is that there won't be any sequels coming to it due to the company going out of business.

reviewText:
This game surprised me.  I read some reveiws that said it was surprisingly good but it still caught me off guard.  I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I am.  It's a pleasant feeling to be surprised these days by a game that seemed to be so resoundingly denounced on release.  I highly recommend playing it, even with all its' flaws, because it's fun and familiar.

Let's get the bad out of the way:
-The first 30 minutes.  It's awkward to control without tweaking because it was absolutely designed to be used with a controller.  If you have one, I recommend using it.  If not, tinker with sensitivity and hotkeys to make it more playable.  The defacto tutorial level is unimpressive, slightly confusing, and rather buggy.  It takes you through each class and weapon type but you don't have to commit just yet.  At this point it seems to be super linear, on rails type of game but push through to the first village and it opens up.
-The camera.  It takes getting used to.  The third person perspective is unfortunate.  While I generally play in third person, not having the option to move the camera is frustrating at times.  This is one of the areas where it's design for consoles is very evident.
-Vanilla.  This isn't really a negative or a positive.  It's what you expect from a game like this.  Some fetch quests, some kill quests, some steal quests, a few factions and schools to join, and the RPG trinity of classes.  Even with some multiclassing, it's still an expected experience class wise.

The Good:
-Rich lore.  If you didn't know, it is written by RA Salvatore and it shows.  Some of the stories feel familiar if you are a fan of his books.  One of the first questlines, The House of Ballads, is very interesting and they continue in the vein throughout.
-Tons of side quests.  You can get lost in sidequests for a few hours with each new area and those discovered in the wild.
-Combat seems simple on the surface (and can remain so if you desire) but with multiclassing can become dynamic and engaging.
-Crafting! I generally only craft because I have to but this system makes it easy.  It is not particularly deep or impressive in it's installation but it is perfect for players like me who don't generally dump a ton of time into it.  I like that you can craft usable items at any point no matter the skill level.  Strength of weapons or armor are based on components used and NOT player skill.  A small but important distiction.

This game is everything you expect from an open world RPG in the Elder Scrolls vein.  Why would that be a bad thing?  Just because it has been done before doesn't mean it can't be done again and done well.  Pick it up and have fun with it, I know I have.

reviewText: So take World of Warcraft and Fable-esque art style and questing but add dynamic combat mechanics akin to Darksiders or Devil May Cry and you get Kingdoms of Amalur. While the story is somewhat lackluster and dull, the open ended exploration of vivid Amalur and it's treasures/loot make up for it shortcomings. The character builds consist of classic dungeon crawling roles of the Warrior, the Mage and the Rogue or combinations of the three classes which offer unique combat approaches. Unlike other open world RPGs ,like Skyrim, you are able to completely respec a character's perk points (for a fee) if you feel you made a bad decision in their allocation or just want a change of pace. Almost 25 hours into this game and I feel I've only scratched the surface. Great buy!

reviewText: I've always felt RPGs to be a bit different than other types of games. They require time, dedication, and skill. But in return, they give you one of the greatest possible benifits- no, not a drip for your sensory systems or endorphins, but an endless creativity and a bueatiful world. That being said, creating a game is different from creating a painting. It can't just look good, it must be fun to play, fun to interact with, fun to experience. And while when many think of RPG, TES comes to mind, I think Amalur: Reckoning is one of those games that is sorely missed. It carries you into a colerfull, viberant, world, ripe with imagination and ready for the taking. It gives you what is, in my opinion, a better system than any other game- it allows you to have the freedom of skyrim, but also the classical class system and skill trees. The gameplay is fun, the world is simply gourgeous, and the lore is plentiful. This is one hell of a game you would not want to miss.\n\n(NOTE: I am a PC gamer, however, I find this game is much more enjoyable with Xbox 360 controller. Its not meant for it, but it sure should be!)

reviewText:
Very expansive world with a lot of atmospheric variety.  Very beautiful.  Dungeons got a little cut and paste, which was disappointing, but they're dungeons and caves.

Controls are pretty intuitive on KB&M, depending on your playstyle.  You can also respec at any point for a fee if you realize you messed up your build.  There are some bugs that affect your inventory (stuff that won't leave your inventory and just take up space), but the game as a whole is very polished.  Crafting is the best way to get good gear, so invest some points in blacksmithing.  Expect to do a lot of running everywhere.  This was an MMO that switched gears mid-development, so you won't get mounts to make travel faster to undiscovered locations. There is fast travel to to discovered locations, which helps.

The DLCs were enjoyable and worth the extra money.  You can also continue to explore after you go through the main quest line to mop up anything you missed.  7.5/10.

reviewText: Wow... what an unsung gem of a game, I would guess its very approachable from a variety of skill levels. The action oriented combat is great. There is also a huge story and lots of well acted voice dialog.\n\nIf I showed this to my Fiance she would probably keep the controller for herself. I guess I'll eventually have to show her because she loves art and creative media. Kingsoms of Amalur really is that pretty, once she starts getting the hang of the controls (which are easy to use, while also having depth) we'll have one more thing we like to share.

reviewText: An excelent game. It has a level of character customizability that rivals and possibly surpasses the Elder Scrolls series. Your ability to thoroughly customize your character's powers and abilities adds a level of forthought to who you want your character to be while you fight. If you don't like the way your stats are progressing, then you can wipe the slate clean and start over. Through the course of the story line, you could have a warrior, a mage, a rogue, a combination of any two, or all three. Plus, your ability to sneak, forge, craft potions, find hdden items and other such skills are seperate from the combat skill trees. You could have a warrior with an insanely high sneaking and discovering items skills, or a thief that likes to forge weapons and armor. Basically, this game is definately worth playing, Nine out of ten, I'd say.

reviewText:
Eh, it's okay. There is a massive amount of content in the game, so it is a definitive timesink, which is great for open worlds at the scale of this one. But, I found the lore difficult to understand, story old, tried and true. I can't get into it as much as I would like, and much like Skyrim, after a while, it just becomes Dungeon/Cave Simulator. Go in hole, kill that, come back. At least there's fast travel.

It's better suited to be played with a controller, but my biggest gripe is the FOV: holy jesus it's practically stuck to the back of the character's head. If you do pick up the game, either expect motion sickness, or install an FOV fix, such as Widescreen Fixer.

It's worth picking up and playing, you might enjoy it more than I did, but it's no masterpiece.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game made me feel like a kid again.

I've played a ton of games to the point where I felt like nothing was new, but this is defintely a unique game.

It's graphics look pretty good for it's time. It's got more of a fantasy look than anything and they certainly did a good job on that. While in combat everything looks really smooth and it's fun to look at... especially those finishers, oh man. Sometimes the combat is a little clunky though, mostly regarding the camera. It doesn't have a lock on feature so sometimes it's a little frustrating when you're trying to lock target onto someone else. With that aside, the combat is still great.

Usually with an RPG, you'll have to go down a specific specialization to be powerful. That mostly holds true in this game, though you can still spread your talents more thin and still not do underwhelming damage.

There's lots and lots and lots of quests. You might not even find all of them which makes this game great. Though it's no Elder Scrolls size, it's still a large game. Because you can make so many different characters and take different quest paths, it's definitely got great replay value. I'd certainly reccomend this game.

9/10

I had originally played this on the console {Xbox360} and I enjoyed playing it for hours at a time. I believe I spent a good two hundred hours on the side quests and factions alone.

I decided to purchase this game on Steam while it was on sale {Because I am cheap haha.} and it was an amazing purchase. It is as fun as a remember.

As for the keyboard controls, I had to rebind most of them to suit my hand placement. The Wakening mode finisher is difficult for me with a laggy computer to pull off, but it is still rewarding to see those animations.

I would rate this game a nine of ten.

reviewText:
7/10

This open world single player frpg is no Skyrim(what else is?), but it has the potential to engross you for many hours if you like this type of game.  The game suffers a bit from feeling like it was a template for an MMO more than being designed strictly as a single player frpg.


PROs
+Lots of content -- skills, items, quests, zones
+Action combat
+Open world (sort of)
+Fully voiced NPCs
+No significant bugs encountered
+Fate weaving was an interesting game mechanic

CONs
-No jump key
-Narrow zones in lieu of a true open world
-Cartoony graphics reminiscent of WoW.  Low polygons with vibrant coloring
-Mildly annoying inventory management, (mostly)mitigated by fast travel. and an in game stash
-A little slow at first


+/-  The lore in the game was fairly deep, but I personally did not find the lore(or story for that matter) particularly compelling.  ymmv.

+/-  Not particularly difficult.  Some may say too easy.

Conclusion:  Holy crap,did you really read everything to this point?   cough....  If you are between AAA games, can find this on sale, and have a hankering for a big single player frpg, this may be a game you should try.

reviewText:
Skyrim is the starting point:

Replace complete open world with distinct areas.

You now have something more closely resembling KOA - Reckoning.

reviewText:
Se você pensa em que esse jogo está abaixo das expectativas, com toda certeza você está enganado. Eu fui assim em relação a ele, até joga-lo.

E mudei totalmente meu ver, é um daqueles jogos que são pouco divulgados, mas merecem o reconhecimento.

O jogo se passa no Reino de Amalur, onde você é um escolhido do '' Destino '', algo que torna as coisas ao redor mudarem, e você é o principal protagonista de um certo experimento ter dado certo e escolhido para impedir o mal ( Clichê que nunca acaba. )

Mas, vendo ao mundo vasto que Amalur mostra, sidequests são quase infinitas, dungeons são várias e os cenários,  super bem feitos e diferenciados.

Eu já vi isso em vários outros jogos, mas de qualquer forma vale ressaltar o elemento mais ♥♥♥♥ que KoA abrange:  o Combate Hack N' Slash.
Não é como em RPGs clássicos que você '' de repente '' encontra um inimigo, ou em uma batalha em turnos, é tudo naquele momento, você viu o inimigo e ja começa a pancadaria, independente do ambiente que for, todos os movimentos acontecem e fluem extremamente bem, sem um único erro ou bug. E até com 4 inimigos a sua frente, é possível enfrentá-los todos ao mesmo tempo, focando todos ao modo que você quiser, através de ataques corpo-a-corpo, longo alcance e magia.

Isso já determina as 3 classes, que, apesar de serem poucas, possuem habilidades significativas para cada uma das classes.
Exemplo: Não é possível ser Mago do Fogo ou do Gelo, Mago é Mago, você usa
tanto fogo, como gelo, eletricidade, e até sumona um esqueleto para lhe ajudar.
Um fator legal das classes é você poder misturar uma com a outra, podendo fazer um guerreiro + mago, ou assassino + guerreiro, e por ai vai.
Mas claro, é possível seguir uma skill tree só, mas eu acho meio chato sinceramente, já que o jogo oferece você poder misturar os combos de cada classe para acabar com os inimigos.
O level máximo do jogo é 40, achei baixo, mas é o suficiente para você poder aprender todas as skills da '' árvore '' da sua classe.

A quantidade em termos de itens são poucas, porém há muitas variações de um mesmo item, incluindo raros,lendários e os sets ( que fazem parte de um combo de equipamentos ).

No jogo também são incluídas facções, que é possível se juntar,assim obtendo mais sidequests e seguir a mainquest dessas facções, são ao total 7 facções no jogo. Descubra por si mesmo auhauhau

Há também as cartas, que são obtidas de várias maneiras, e oferecem ao jogador bônus exclusivos, como maior dano, regeneração de vida, e por ai vai.
Dentro desse esquema existem também as lorestones, que contam poesias e poemas sobre Amalur, achando um set completo de lorestones, você ganha bônus para algo específico também,


Falei muito bem dele até agora, mas KoA contém seus pontos negativos também.

Um deles é o Summon da skill de Mago, que aparentemente não fica maior ou mais parrudo quanto mais ele upa, ele aprende novos combos para abater os inimigos. Achei diferente, porém estou acostumado com os summons parrudos do Diablo II, auahuahuah.
Outra coisa são os personagens, todos são muito bonitinhos, coloridos, mas isso é o estilo do jogo mesmo, mas é impossível você ficar horrendo no jogo, é mais fácil ficar com uma aparência bizonha e estranha.

Além disso, tem certos NPCs extremamente fracos em relação a personalidade, uns 70% do jogo, então não espere muito deles. Claro que tem alguns que te acompanham pelo resto do jogo, que obviamente vão estar bem melhores que os outros.

Não há companions permanentes, só temporários.

BUGS malignos, como som atrasado, acontecem algumas vezes, ou também o jogo fica mudo, mas volta ao normal.

FInalizando, KoA é um daqueles RPGs que você com certeza não bota fé por não seguir os estilos clássicos como FF, Tactics Ogre, Diablo II, ES,etc.
Mas, mostra por um lado, uma obra prima que conseguiu colocar o combate como maior foco do jogo, coisa que poucos não focam e muitos gostariam de ver a ação tomar '' ao vivo '', um mundo incrível para explorar, itens para achar e melhorar e seu personagem, e principalmente, um caminho a escolher para o seu Destino.

8/10.

reviewText:
If you like RPG's then this one is worth a look. When it comes on special, grab it and all the DLC's.

The good:
Nice graphics.
Large open world.
Entertaining story lines across most quests.
I enjoyed the combat system pairing both physical and magic attacks.

The bad:
As the dev house ran out of money / time, some of the quests and cut scenes are buggy but this does not detract from the overall experience. The entertainment value outwieghed the few minor bugs.
I did encounter one major bug that resulted in an incomplete quest. The quest dialog says that you should pick pocket one of the NPC's, which I did. However, the quest did not progress. I then discovered, in the quests menu, that you should kill the NPC and then recover the items.

All in all, a good game and worth it when it comes on special.

reviewText:
I have so much to say about Kingdoms! This is one of my all time favorite RPG games. The battles can be a bit repetative and you can count on your enemy throwing the same fight combo at you time and time again (which makes it pretty easy to get those parry achievements) The story line is huge! and there is so much to do in this game which brings me to my first complaint... the level cap :( You can reach the level cap by just doing the main factions. The first time i beat the main story line i was a little bummed to learn of the level cap. I mean who doesnt like to watch their XP sky rocket when you finally beat that main pain in the a** boss?! However, i just started a new game, leveled up the weapons i knew i loved and kept on going.
Sometimes the camera view got a bit wonky, its hard to fight when the camera decides to view only the ground lol but it is possible. Just a slight annoyance.

The open world is also huge! There are tons of side quests to keep you busy for quite awhile. I love the Fast Travel option, which lets be honest, who doesnt just love spending half the game walking from end of the map to other?! (insert sarcastic gaze) Fast Travel really really helps with a map that is this big.
I downloaded The Teeth of Narcos DLC after i beat the game the first time. It's okay.... The underground sewer is a bit of a maze and isnt as open" as the main game map
date: but it's still pretty fun. Again
recommended: it brings up the level cap that sucks....\n\nThe game says Partial Controller Support but after 200 somthing hours i would have to say that its pretty much full controller. Has anyone heard of a Kingdoms 2?"

reviewText:
A cohesive narrative and vibrant visuals bring the world of Amalur to life.

As I glance through some other user reviews I see a lot of positive comparisons to some of the leaders of the RPG genre: Skyrim, Guild Wars 2, Fable, Diablo and Torchlight. Personally I saw the closest resemblance to World of Warcraft with its visuals and questing system. However, this is no clone of a game. It has a unique identity that, in part, is made from borrowing successful traits from these other titles. What stands out most strongly to me about Kingdoms of Amalur is its narrative and world lore. It presents fresh ideas and throughout my 95+ hours (including 210 quests completed) with the game it always felt consistent, like the developers shared a unified vision of what they wanted this world to be.

Without discussing any specific plot points, I'll say that things begin on a high note and intrigued me right off the bat with a mystery surrounding who this character you are playing as is. It is a special feat in my mind to be able to have a personalized, voiceless protagonist that you are expected to project yourself into also have a predetermined, very interesting back story of their own. Too often these types of characters are just a boring blank slate.

My sense of progression through this world was wonderful. Your journey begins far from a major warzone and consequently you merely hear stories about it. As you advance closer you begin to see more immediate effects like sons and daughters gone off to fight or altered local economies. Eventually you'll see large refugee camps causing overcrowding problems and burned down towns before reaching the warfront itself. By and large, the settings you visit along the way stand apart from each other both visually and in local story. The exceptions to this are some of the dungeons that look and play very similarly, just with different layouts and quest objectives to fulfill. For a game already so big I think it would have benefited from cutting some of them out.

All dialogue is voice acted and of good quality. There is some noticeable reuse of voice actors among NPCs, but that is excusable for a game of this size. I would rather see good voice actors reused than bad voice actors brought in in greater numbers.

Combat, unfortunately, is just adequate. There isn't enough depth here to stay compelling throughout. There is a nice mix of weapon types that all control very differently, but you're likely to pick one or two early on and stick with them. Magic brings some cool spells to the fray but are very limited in number. Leveling up is a good, customizable system that does gradually add new abilities, but not enough to keep things from going stale. To be clear, I never got to a point of hating battles. However, a combination of things getting too easy by the end, the long length of the game and repetition of enemy types eventually sucked a lot of the enjoyment out of it. I will warn you that it is possible to become over leveled if you do all side quests as you find them. Google Amalur Wiki overlevel" to find a guide for avoiding this.

I'll wrap things up with a few more minor critiques. Loot is dealt out in such volume that inventory management becomes a chore (similar to many Diabloesque games). Despite this abundance of gear it was surprisingly infrequent how often I found something better than what I was wearing. Also
date: before long I had more money than things to do with it. I play most games on Normal difficulty
hoursPlayed: but didn't find enough challenge here so I suggest playing on Hard to most players. The orchestral score was competently produced but lacked the artistry to make it memorable.\n\nOverall
voteText: Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a fantastic
helpfulPercent: expansive experience that could have benefited from seeing its great length reined in a little bit."

reviewText:
Kingdoms of Amalur is a good Action-RPG in its own right.

It has plenty of loot drops, a very action oriented battle system and a very good skill tree.
The skills are fun to explore and satisfying to combine, to find your own playstyle.
The quests usually range from killing X to talk to Y and fetch Z. Nothing new here.
The game features a huge map, which is unfortunately not a single map, like in Skyrim,
but large Zones that are connected without a loading screen.

Art style and graphics are very colourful, yet gorgeous, comic-esque.
And although it looks a little like Torchlight, it features rather bloddy finishing combos.

If you are in need of easy action without a deep story KoA might capture you for hours,
until something better" comes along.
It's not Skyrim and it does not try to be
date: but it's also not as mature

reviewText: I had heard that this game was too similar to an MMORPG without actually being one to be fun, but these claims were wrong. Certainly, the quest system is a degree like an MMO's, but it was nowhere near as monotonous, and I went through the game doing every quest for every region, and only became tired of that when I had went through every piece of land on the lefternmost (see: largest) continent, and was about 40 hours in. The combat is fantastic. I only played as a warrior, but the moves were so stylish, and made you feel so powerful, that I never got tired of fighting. The challenge is kept consistent all the way through, and the gameplay and character customization overshadow the admitably awful story and characters (that fortune-teller dude that follows you throughout the game is badass, though, as is your gnome buddy). I strongly recommend this. One playthrough, including DLC, will get you 50+ hours, and it is certainly replayable.

reviewText:
Hands on the table, I've yet to explain such a great experience as I have been having with this game, thus far. Amalur: Reckoning, has become a favorite in a matter of moments, to me.

If you are in search of a story-backed, heavily armored RPG, or something to bring an emotional (and nostalgic) rememberance to you. THIS IS IT!
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning has brought back to me the same nostalgia of games such as, Fable, Morrowind, and other timeless classics that brought in a new era of RPG gaming.

9.3/10 Story
8/10 Graphics
10/10 Content
8/10 UI/Combat Mechanics
10/10 Replay Value

The story is unique and enthralling from my point of view as the player, many bonds formed in the game. Reckoning has an exciting amount of information to learn for almost every NPC character as well, there is lots to learn, and always a bonus!

Graphics are intriguing, lots of intuitive graphic inspirations which look and feel similar to games such as WoW, Prince of Persia, Fable 2, and The Last Remnant.

I could not ask for ANY more content from this game, personally. The content that has been provided, is incredible. It takes a keen eye to see all the little details put into the fabrics of this game, and there is a bountiful amount of things to do in this game, never boring.

As for the UI of this game, it's not clunky" or "misplaced"

reviewText: A decent game with bright visuals and a long runtime.  The story is confusing and forgettable, but decent for an RPG. reviewText:
Solid old fashioned RPG fun.
That's the description I keep thinking about all the time I've been playing. In fact I'm having too much fun to admit this game has flaws - which it definitely does but I just don't care. Because there's that itch and it's being thoroughly scratched, and if you need proof just start counting how many times I'm about to use the word fun. ;) And if counting isn't your thing, there is an actual demo (shocking, I know), so ignore me and try the game yourself.

So why is it fun? Being able to mix and match any class you can come up with is fun. Respeccing anytime you feel like it (for a fee) is fun. The loot is good, diverse and stays interesting. Exploration is very much rewarded. And alone these elements mean: I just found an interesting legendary item in a chest behind a weird crevice that I had no reason to go to

reviewText:
This game is one of the best RPGs you could buy.
With a combat system to easily pick up and retain, a character class system to mix and match for great effect, a crafting system that is actually beneficial to your character's progression and a story that only pulls you in once you begin, it's fair to say that you'll get your money's worth with every single penny.

reviewText:
This game is full of content, not to mention if you add the dlc's to it.
There is a load of Weapons and Armours, all sorts of items to upgrade with and its great! The leveling up system is very nice and really makes you think about what you're upgrading, For both the combat and the skills.
There are many quests to do and so many more side quests, the faction quests are great for lore as well.
The final boss fights are very well laid out and make you create a plan of attack, sometimes its fun to just go nuts as well.

Of course there are some things that aren't the best, for instance the prices of items and such can be fairly unbalanced and if you are not careful can end up wasting a big chunk of your gold.
The camera angles can be tricky to get use to, especially if you play a lot of other games that all use a different camera style. It can be a bit of a nuicence that you can zoom your camera or lock/unlock it.

But other then that this game is absolutley amazing, graphically and visually. Audio and musicaly and combat balance and all that, offering a wide variety of content it is a game that is worth buy and spending hours into nights of playing.

reviewText: I was looking for a Fantasy Rpg to play and found this, I'd finished Skyrim and was looking for another great experience. While it didn't live up to my expectations (which were probably far to high considering what I was comparing it to) but I found it nevertheless to be an enchanting game, beautiful music, wonderful scenery, nice graphics, combat had just enough variety to not be tedious and boring. My favorite part of it all would have to be going around finishing side quests after the main story. Besides Skyrim I've never actually enjoyed this process in other games, it just felt repetative beating foe after foe with my godlike powers, but in this, the music and scenery just made it magical. I'd reccomend this to anyone wanting a Fantasy Rpg  game that's comfortable and fun to play. 8/10

reviewText:
★★★☆☆

When i was playing mass effect 2 on xbox 360, I had chance to play kingdoms of amalur (as KOA) demo version. And this demo game gave me a good time. So i bought this one.

Anyway that's personal history. :) Return to the subject, 'KOA' presents the new fantasy world about 'Rule of Cycle', 'Immortal Fea', 'Crystal War', 'Fateless One'... and so on. And these things are showed with beautiful graphic (not mean good quality).

Also this game contains many thing to do. After tutorial, you will be faced a lot of quests. Even sometimes these quests make me confusing. You can collect regents or shards to create potions or gems. And you can breakdown equipment and salvage gears to make weapons or armors.

And battle system is good. Even this is a RPG game. You can against your enemy by combo, air combo, combat ability and reckoning mode. Various weapons, skills, destinies (like specialized jobs) give you joyful choice. Even you think 'I made a wrong choices', don't worry, you can return to level 1 with all skill points. And reckoning mode is awesome, you become a powerful one and you can do fate-shift (like finish blow). I always felt catharsis when i finished a strong enemy by fate-shift.

But 'KOA' also has bad things. First and Worst thing is '38 Studios (developer of 'KOA') was closed without 'KOA' licence sold. That means no more updates, DLCs and 'Kingdoms of Amalur II' :(

And character customization is awful. May be, you have bad feeling, when you make your player. Because character customization has very little selections to make your face. Then your worry become a problem of game play. You can see  a NPC what have exactly same your face with different hair color. But that's not a problem, i can imagine he is a my doppelganger or unknown my brother who was seperated at childhood (in game story). But real problem is same faces NPCs are too many to focus story line. For example, You will meet a mentor who guide you in arcana faction quest, and he will send you to the archimage. (I skip many things to prevent spoiler). Then... you will see a same mentor face archimage with white hair. WTF, Even they are major NPCs of faction quest, they have same face!!! except hair color!!!! This problem will teases you until final battle.

Other thing is the low level cap. If you are a person who complete all quest in the game (not repeat quests), you can reach level 40 (max level), soon. In my case, i could reach level 40 after siege of mel senshir. Probably i could do that because i finished 'The Legend of Dead Kel' and 'Teeth of Naros' before cross the ocean. Then i lost my purpose of side quests and battles. Level cap must be higher than level 40 to make player can push forward.

Anyway 'KOA' is a good RPG game. If it was not, i didn't get all achievements of this game. 'KOA' is a new IP game what has potential to be a great franchise game. But it's a shame, future of 'KOA' is unclear.

reviewText:
This is pretty late to the game, since Kingdoms has been out for years now, but I think it's important to review a game I love this much. I have more hours into this game than almost any other, and for good reason. The story is pretty extensive, and the sidequests are mostly worth doing, unlike some more recent RPG's.

Pros:
-Good main storyline
-Easy to learn combat system
-Excellent DLC
-A weapon crafting system that makes your efforts count
-Ability to respec easily later in the game

Neutral:
-Built-in level cap doesn't allow for maximized characters
-Even without maxed abilities, the game isn't difficult to beat

Cons:
-The side stories are extremely repetitive and predictable
-Speed is heavily favored over power


I know not everyone will agree with some of my points, especially the last one. But those are my takes on it. I have played it all the way through, and have created many characters, and I have just loved it.

reviewText:
A main storyline playthrough of the game itself is only 26 or so hours. Why the ♥♥♥♥ would I say ONLY? The game has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (200+ hours) of content in sidequests and other content. 200 HOURS!! That's right, crazy.

So you're sold on the ammount of content, right? But what of the QUALITY. Well, I can confirm each quest, especially a ton of the side quests, has an interesting and unique story that fits into the huge ammount content in this lore filled world. Many of the side quests I've seen allow for alternate rewards and task changing interaction through fully voice-acted dialogue based around your pursuasion (charisma in other games) skill. (Making tue skill actually useful, unlike some games.)

The character destiny cards systems encourages awesome hyhbrids of different combat styles and abilities from the three main branches where you can invest ability points. These cards are unlocked based on what trees you invest your AP to add bonus stats and even complete changes to your abilities to make yourself into the exact blend of abilities and strengths you desire.

The combat itself introduces a number of skill based fighting mechanics that never seem to lose their weighty and epic feel. This is only added to in the fact that you can make any number of crazy class combinations to tailor your combat experience. Not to mention the weapon and gear options that are also complimented by the epic skills system.

The complexity and depth added in the alchemy, blacksmithing, detect hidden, dispelling, lockpicking, mercantile, pursuasion, sagecraft, and stealth skills furthurs the great sense of benefit you get from investing in one skill each level. Each skill builds to greater perks as you invest furthur along in one particular skill, but the gut wrenching decisions you face in deciding where to invest next are what makes you realize the importance of each skill, and the role they serve.

The progression of the game overall is at pretty much whatever pace you play at. If you want to rush to train for that next ability, do it. You will be fine, although you might want to bring some extra potions. If instead you want to do some side quests and join guilds for added benefits and rewards, do it. In fact, you can maintain a balance of both.

The only qualm (not even that) I have is that if you progress to a furthur area and return to do some quests, they can in some cases seem too easy after becoming more powerful. Which, I don't see it really as a game flaw, because it is just the nature of the RPG genre. For example: after having defeated a dragon and then returning to kill some slimes of any typical rpg would be a walk in the park.

I've been through just the tip of the iceberg, and there lies a journey of trials and triumph awaiting you. So,
please buy this game, not for me, but yourself. You'll be glad you did.
