reviewText: Good looking combat, great writing/story (R.A. Salvatore) and a different kind of fantasy RPG experience.  It isn't as immersive as the Elderscrolls games and can get pretty boring as the side quests design is pretty weak. Combat is awesome looking but does quickly become very repetitive. That said, for anyone looking for an easy-to-play RPG, KoA does a pretty good job at entertaining. If you're a fantasy RPG gamer, do yourself a favor and try this game.

reviewText: Be prepared for a lot of monotony. It's good monotony, but monotony. Combat system is solid, as is the class system. Be a rogue/warrior/mage, and then some mixture of two or all of them later down based on the skills you get. Besides possibly Alyn Shir, there aren't really any memorable characters or particularly crystallizing moments. I have fun with it, but really only because it's somewhat mindless and doesn't take a lot of mental involvement. Wait for a sale though :o\n\nOh, and play on hard. Even on hard it's pretty easy.

reviewText: My favourite RPG by far, Kingdoms of Amalur replace the typically slow-paced RPG into a seamless story-telling experience featuring lots of great actions and combinations often seen only in action-games.\n\nWhat make this game especially special? Lorestones. Like the random recordings found in games like BioShock and Batman: Arkham series, the lorestones in KOA feature high quality recording, feature bard-like tunes, proses on lores and random musings from the citizens.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
At time of writing it is 2:40 a.m. so I'm ranting

BUT WHAT A GAME HOLY ****

Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a gigantic map of living, breathing npcs woven together by a glossy art style and quirky, sarcastic tones for every serious moment. It prides itself for having a wide selection of combat and adventuring styles, from a measly peasant to a brutal war-mage. You'll find loot for days and a fighting system that delivers satisfying crunches with every impact. I picked up six different builds before I settled on one that fit a medium-range capacity with all the abilities to deal with enemies of every calibre. The game punishes as much as it rains down riches upon you, the player. Keep your eyes peeled and your hands on your keyboard or controller, 'cause there's plenty of things to do from killing to talking to throwing out junk to getting blown up by that one annoying trap to crafting MORE gems to discovering an ancient ruin of a city to getting rejected by that one hottie of an elf. Don't ever trust the game to hold your hand; take what you get and give nothing back.

Copious praise aside, there were a few factors which tripped over and otherwise pleasant gameplay experience.

There were bugs galore, from broken quests to broken npcs to missing items to items stuck in your inventory. A few of the colour palettes used were neon-nized to the point of frying the rods and cones in your eyeballs. There was so much story in the form of books that if you were to read all that AND read the npc dialogue AND run around looking for treasure, you'd be in the space age before you finished. The skill slotting menu and subsequent settings metres were broken in that they wouldn't move when dragged. Lastly, THERE WERE ONLY 2 DLCS ;_______________;

I first got this game when I saw Youtuber @SSoHpkc playing it and it looked fun as hell

It really was fun as hell.

BUY IT

reviewText:
At time of writing it is 2:40 a.m. so I'm ranting

BUT WHAT A GAME HOLY ****

Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a gigantic map of living, breathing npcs woven together by a glossy art style and quirky, sarcastic tones for every serious moment. It prides itself for having a wide selection of combat and adventuring styles, from a measly peasant to a brutal war-mage. You'll find loot for days and a fighting system that delivers satisfying crunches with every impact. I picked up six different builds before I settled on one that fit a medium-range capacity with all the abilities to deal with enemies of every calibre. The game punishes as much as it rains down riches upon you, the player. Keep your eyes peeled and your hands on your keyboard or controller, 'cause there's plenty of things to do from killing to talking to throwing out junk to getting blown up by that one annoying trap to crafting MORE gems to discovering an ancient ruin of a city to getting rejected by that one hottie of an elf. Don't ever trust the game to hold your hand; take what you get and give nothing back.

Copious praise aside, there were a few factors which tripped over and otherwise pleasant gameplay experience.

There were bugs galore, from broken quests to broken npcs to missing items to items stuck in your inventory. A few of the colour palettes used were neon-nized to the point of frying the rods and cones in your eyeballs. There was so much story in the form of books that if you were to read all that AND read the npc dialogue AND run around looking for treasure, you'd be in the space age before you finished. The skill slotting menu and subsequent settings metres were broken in that they wouldn't move when dragged. Lastly, THERE WERE ONLY 2 DLCS ;_______________;

I first got this game when I saw Youtuber @SSoHpkc playing it and it looked fun as hell

It really was fun as hell.

BUY IT

reviewText:
The best way I could describe this game is World of Warcraft meets Skyrim.

Amalur has a lot going for it in the way of efficient dialogue, skilled voice actors, spectacular combat animations, and masterful music.

Amalur falters, however, in inheriting the problems of WoW and Skyrim: frustrating inventory system (at the beginning of the game when you don't have a Stash yet), tedious quests, repetitive fights, very long travel distances, and not the most engaging plotline I've followed.  The game kind of feels like it's trying to be too much for too many people; the way instructions are worded makes one think this were an introductory RPG (as compared to much more detail-oriented games like Divinity).  This irked me, strangely.

I still recommend the game.  It's not bad" per se
date: but falls short on too many levels to keep it from holding more profound players.  It's a 60-hour hack'n'slash with some great role-playing bits (not in terms of the story
hoursPlayed: but in how you want to approach combat) that you might like in spite of the amount of running you do.  Suggest picking it up on a sale."

reviewText:
Wow, Kingdoms of Amalur was a GOOD game. From beging to end i never felt that this game really deserved the bad rap that it got. However I do understand that this game has its issues and there are far more polished and more sophistcated RPG titles out there. But i blieve the late 38 studios did a great job with this title, with this being its first and now only ever game the company has produced i blieve it deserves the cult status it has slowly achieved. The story, the lore and the characters is were this game really shines, its ingossing and it makes you feel like you are a part of the world, and i am truely hoping that one day a studio, perhaps Obsedian, will save the franchise and make a much wanted sequal.
Now, there are areas that may turn people away, the combat is invigorating at first but quickly becomes quite repedative, and many of the side quests feel like you are just visting the same dungeon and the doing the  same objective over and over again. Although if you just stick to the main quest, you shouldnt come across this problem. The crafting system is also very limited and is pretty forgettable with the game's competitors blowing it out of the park. But that said it isn't bad either. With the fast leveling up, it feels like the crafting becomes more of a novelty in the late game.
So in conclusion, 38 studios, now gone will not be forgotten with this hidden gem in Amalur. I blieve the narrative of the game alone is enough to warrent interest from a new studio to give this ip another chance. Over all a good game, with some sub par RPG elements but with an amazing story and lore. Well worth buying during a steam sale.
Score: 7.5
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: An under the cover game, dwarfed by other releases such as the Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, this game should be viewed in greater light and strength. An addictive expansive world fuelled by a real fantastical scenario and setting, Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning brings strong RPG elements to an otherwise uncomplicated genre. Though this game is stuck between an MMO and a traditional RPG, its combat, crafting and magical elements make this game a strong condendor for anyone looking to play an addictive, massive world game. The downsides to this game may be considerable for some: the purely linear main campaign, the massive open world with no fast travel and lack of considerable and ultimately interesting quests. Nevertheless, it makes up for these pitfalls in interesting dialogue that is both well tohugh out and witty. It is a real blast for any gamer. 8/10

reviewText:
Just got done beating this game, its DLC and numerous side quests.  It's the most fun I've had with a game in quite a while and highly recommend it.  I'm a fan of action RPG games like Diablo, Skyrim, etc. but not too much of a fan of Witcher (too many lengthy story pauses) and Dragon Age (clunky keyboard/mouse combat).

This game has a great story woven throughout, and the excellent keyboard/mouse controls coupled with so many places to explore really won me over.   The level designs are excellent and each region of the game world really feels unique.  I also loved the reckoning mode which slows everything down and allows you to perform special kills which were very satisfying.  The character voice narratives are excellently done too.  Quest markers were easy to follow, and didn't experience a single crash during my entire playthrough, unlike with the Gothic and Sacred games which disappointed me in this regard.

If I had to give slight" complaints
date: I would say the overabundance of purple unique items.  Making it more rarer to obtain these unique items would have given a greater sense of excitement when finding one.  Also
recommended: you will want to increase the difficulty which is not a usual practice of mine as I typically play games on Casual or Don't Hurt Me mode.  The easiest difficult option in this game is just way to easy.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: an outstanding game for those PC gamers who want a great exploratory experience and fun combat to boot.  I work for a living and don't want to be overly challenged when I find some time to game
voteText: and this game really hit the mark.  I give this game a 10 out of 10."

reviewText:
I never understood why I never heard of this game and no one seemed to play it.  (According to RPS commenters, it had a crappy outsourced demo, was overpriced, came out same time as skyrim.: http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2013/02/26/why-didnt-everyone-play-kingdoms-of-amalur/#comments )

Anyways, I absolutely loved this game.  While I only put 12 hours on my steam copy so far, I probably played ~100 on a different account, and it was some of the most enjoyable gaming I've ever done.

Maybe I'm just weird but I love single-player games, and don't really touch multiplayer - I put hundreds of hours into Diablo 1-2-3 offline.  I hear there are a lot of bugs, but I don't remember any.  It was polished, smooth, visually gorgeous and vibrant, and addictive as hell.

Combat was just badass.  Seriously, I just saw some of the screenshots on the steam page, and I forgot how amazingly fun combat was, especially with the more unusual weapons like chakras.  This game had one of the most satisfying combat systems I've ever seen.

Looks like it's no longer expensive, it's easily worth anything under $20 if you enjoy ARPGs at all, I liken it to Diablo/Torchlight mixed with something like Devil May Cry or fast-paced fluid combat systems.  It's no Elder Scrolls game, but if you play it casually and just expect to grind through a bunch of enemies surrounded by lovely scenery and have fun for a while, it's totally worth it.

reviewText:
A fairly unsung RPG in its own right, not sure what I haven't heard that much about it. Nabbed it, plus the DLC during a major sale, getting it all for 10$ though it's certainly worth the full price of admission as this will take ~40 hours or more of your time.

The game feels like a mix of Fable and the earlier Bioware games such as Mass Effect, Jade Empire, and Knights of the Old republic, though it's a shinier variant of all of those. It has the aesthetic and music of Fable but with a Bioware-esque RPG mixture.

It's not a complicated game to be sure. The dialog doesn't affect much of what you do and there are no companions to fiddle around with.

I'd certainly recommend it, especially if you're a fan of all the other games listed and have played the rest of them to death. This will be refreshing.

reviewText:
Quick review after 40+ hours in the game (I play a lot offline, it doesn't count those usually).

First, for those of you wondering, this game plays without a hitch on an i5-3450 with a mere Intel HD 2500 gpu, on Windows 7-64 bit with 16 GB RAM at 1360x768 with no framerate slowdowns.  It probably will play on Intel laptops with at least an Intel HD 2500 gpu, that's impressive.

The combat is a lot like Darksiders or The Witcher 1.  Basically, you fight in a chain of attacks, usually moving in with each step in the chain.   There are abilities attached to each type of weapon.  You can fight with Daggers, Fae Daggers, Longsword, Chakram, Great Sword, Staff, Sceptre, Bow.   Each of these has a specialty tree where you learn additional passive and active abilities.   The active abilities have certain effects with certain special maneuvers learned.  So a Chakram attack can be held down with left click to create a large defensive spin area attack that applies the magic effect of the Chakram (burning, shock, etc) on everyone in the spin area.   It's quite simple to do and understand.

One of the beauties of this game is that every maneuver or ability you learn has a short movie in-game to examine, even before you learn it.  This gives you a good sense of the timing to achieve it and how it works.   A visual approach is used in almost everything.

And the visuals are impressive.  You have a long view  of the terrain before any level of details lower and if cautious can often see your unaware enemy before you must engage, allowing you to avoid many engagements.  (There are ambushes though, and some enemies are much more alert, so there is still inevitable excitement in any journey.)  The style is exactly as in the pictures and movies on the Store Page.   You can customize your character a fair amount, nose, eyes, gauntness, coloration, hair almost as much as in Skyrim.   The graphics are in the vein of Warcraft but higher resolution and more detailed.   The scenery is colorful.   The animations are very good, both in combat and not.

The Lore is at least as good as Skyrim.  But to be honest, Bethesda lore is always contradictory and confusing, books often are wrong or disagree with the game.  Amalur has lore also, it is less contradictory and confusing, but it is likewise not consistent with the actual game.  I don't think one should really depend on such Lore as meaningful in either set of games.  The difference is that here, the books tend to agree with the reality in the game.  In Skyrim or Oblivion, or even Morrowind, the Lore does not agree with all that is in the game.  About a third of it is totally wrong, and another third of it is inconsistent or just filler.   You'll find less of those inconsistencies in Amalur, but some exists and some is filler.

Combat is fluid, once learned it is easier than in Bethesda games.   Weapons apply much of the magic damage by the abilities and special moves, so there is a lot of value to loot and to armor.   Loot is easy to come by, one does not need to get the special help loot in one of the DLCs to do well, but the package deal is a good price.   I still have not even opened the DLC loot chest.   The most difficult level is level one, not because the in-game tutorial is hard, it is not, but because at each level you seem to grow stronger faster than the opposition.   Also, because it seems that the game's local monsters do not get stronger as you level, although that's a bit debateable.  They are at least capped in certain regions is my guess.

This means that although you are free to go almost anywhere, which is something sandbox RPG players like, you will find it tougher in the expected areas farther from your beginning and closer to the War's front.   You therefore get a sense of improving power as you level, as well as more flexibility in your skills.

I find the game fair at all difficulty levels, play as you wish, difficulty levels can be changed on the fly, so the game is very user friendly.

The dialog is spoken, and although there may not be quite as much dialog as in Skyrim or Oblivion, it's close to as much, well voiced, and more to the point.   I believe this is an area where the game shines.  Quests seem to make sense, even the side quests have value and of course they make you see all parts of the world while being done.  There are a ton of quests and all dialog whether in a quest or not is well done and germane to either the quest or adding flavor to the game world.

The music, the art, the graphics, the animation, the color palette, the characters, the combat, the quests, the open world, the gameplay, the voicework  -- all combine to give you a full, consistent, enjoyable experience.   It combines the feeling of a personal MMO done right with that of an RPG adventure done right, with good action, lots of story, player progression that matters, and so many ways to achieve things and interact with a world you will care about.

There is little to fault here.   Are you afraid of having too little money ... there are crates that spawn everywhere, they aren't chests but remind one of the common loot crates on the Docks of Oblivion's ports.  Break them and you will get some coins over time.  So money is not an issue, although this is not the best way to make money.   Common enemies will respawn in the wild, perhaps even invading a town from time to time.   The guards will respond, but they can take their time, if you kill these interlopers you get a chance for more loot.  Things like this calm you in feeling you can make progress if you fall behind and that there is safety in familiar places you befriend.   Yet, there are ambushes regularly triggered, making good sense in the game, causing either rebel thiefs or beasts to challenge you in various locations as you simply travel about.  This adds to immersion.  There are many special hidden chests, some not so hidden that you can't find them if you look in every tree trunk or every path off the main beat.   But also there are some skills you can acquire to make your mini-map and map help you find more seriously hidden items that you might not find at all otherwise, even secret doors or secreted areas.  Every skill tree has value and you are not limited to any one class or tree or weapon specialization.  Whether you wish to be a better merchant or find hidden areas as a Thief, or cast many spells as a Mage, or fight as a skilled Warrior, you can always mix and match as well. Reset your skills for a price in gold, re-imagining your character.  If you like, craft potions, enhance weapons, salvage anything.

This is a great game, frequently 75% off, so you will not be disappointed.   I can't speak to whether or not the game is too hard or too easy, I would say it after some adjustment is probably easier than the Elder Scrolls series, but that doesn't make the journey any less enjoyable.   So if you want to travel in a beautiful story world with lots to do, in a more colorful and cartoony world that still has all the detail in graphics and story that you ache for, this is a game to recommend highly to you.

Enjoy.  It is often on sale at 75 % off.   Buy it then.  The complete pack is usually $10 and the main game alone is $5.  It's a shame, these developers deserved a chance to make many more games, they would have been equal to the best.   This game has so many extra features done flawlessly, like the map and the movie clips for skill moves, that one has to wonder how this company ever went broke.   A great shame.

NOTE:  This game does seem to require an EA account, but it's easy to register and works flawlessly otherwise.   For me it checks in via internet with the EA servers for authentication every time it starts up.  It may be possible to play the game without this internet access, but I mention this as information.

reviewText:
This is one masively underrated RPG in my opinion.  A massive world full of people, factions, quests to do, places to explore and experiences to be had, it never received the due praise that it should have received.

I wish more RPGs could be as well thought out and beautiful as this one.

For a single playthrough to experience a near full clear will take well over 100 hours, and that does not even touch the DLC.  At $40, this is an RPG YOU HAVE TO TRY.  The demo includes not only the starter tutorial area"

reviewText:
Here's the tl;dr at the top of the post: Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning is absolutely worth your time.

Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning is an open-world, action RPG created by the unfortunately defunct 38 Strudios. After booting the game and playing the first extended mission, you will quickly realized that a lot of love went into this game. There's not many games out there that feel like the people who made them were making a game that they simply adored and would want to play themselves. However, this is, without a doubt, one of those rare games.



Let's take a look at some bullet points straight from the Steam store page:

- Uncover the secrets of Amalur in hundreds of hours of immersive gameplay, from the vibrant city of Rathir to the vast region of Dalentarth to the grim dungeons of the Brigand Hall Caverns.

This bullet is not exaggerating with the hundreds of hours" bit. I've easily sunk 63 hours (as of this posting) into the game and I have no idea if I'm close to the end. And you know what? I'm fine with that. The story is engaging and the world is full of awesome locations full of interesting people eager to send you even farther out into the world.

One of this game's most amazing strengths is that EVERY SINGLE QUEST has full voice acting. You never have to read a line of text if you don't want to. For me
date: this keeps the game interesting and pushes me to play farther into the story because I actually care about these characters. For once
recommended:
the NPCs are not just cardboard cutouts with text attached to their face. It's incredible what a difference that makes.



Okay so it has a ton of missions and voice acting
hoursPlayed: but does it have a world to support these characters and their stories? Hell yes it does! Take a look at this next point of interest:\n\n- Explore deep levels of lore in a universe steeped in 10
voteText: 000 years of fiction created by New York Times bestselling author R.A. Salvatore.\n\nKingdoms Of Amalur has an Elder Scrolls level of world back story. Every book you find has a story written inside them about the towns
helpfulPercent: cities
votesHelpful: people
votesTotal: and invading monsters. Exploration is rewarded with notes written by local townsfolk about their everyday lives
votesFunny: how they came to be
commentsCount: and their personal demons. Some merchants even keep inventory notes that you can peak at. You can spend hours just talking to individual people in the towns and learn how they feel about certain locations
column16: the legends of old
column17: and events that are likely to happen.\n\nIf you're one who craves lore

reviewText:
Underrated RPG

I bought this game without any anticipations and for what it is I had a lot of  fun, of course it's not the next skyrim or dragon age origins, but there are worse Rpgs to play than this. Although I have to mention it's still in a somewhat unfinished state, which is rather unfornunate :( because this game deserved more!

Lets get to the up and downsides of the game.

Up:
- A big, open world with plenty to explore and varriang landscapes (lush forests, dry deserts, damp swamps, etc.)
- Really intuitive active combat it has some elements of darksiders and devil may cry (you can change between main and secondary weapons on the fly, use magic and can string together long combos *although therefore I recommend playing with a controller)
- Quiet unique main story and setting (you are being killed and revived and therefore being able to change fate itself and later you also get information about your past before you were killed)
- Crafting system (you can salvage any weapon/armor, except legendary and sets and get parts to craft your own weapon/armor and name it)
- Dialogue system (sometimes you are able to persuade people, if your skill is high enough and therefore avoid some encounters)

Down:
- Tasks, secondary quest are pretty boring (many fetch and kill-x-of those quests)
- Crafting system somewhat unbalanced (mid-to-late game if you craft your own equipment you will be pretty overpowered and will kill most enemys with one hit)
- All in all a little bit to easy espacially some boss battles which therefore were pretty anticlimatic xD (minigames to pick locks is pretty easy even with few points in lockpicking *although the dispelling mini game can go eat it man, even with maximum level I still have problems but maybe it's because I suck at those things xD)
- Graphics are average there are some good designed places, but other than that not really outstanding (and little variety in the faces, you will meet a lot of siblings but who knows maybe the genetic pool in Amalur is not really varied, that would explain the almost lack of facial animations espacially the main character which looks as emotional as a wet stone ;D )
- Some bugs and exploits (due to the developer going out of business :( )
- Best played with a controller

All in all it's a decent game, it's a real shame the developers went out of business before they could patch out all the bugs but you still get get enough entertainment if you go into it without expecting the next RPG-Hit.

reviewText:
This is one masively underrated RPG in my opinion.  A massive world full of people, factions, quests to do, places to explore and experiences to be had, it never received the due praise that it should have received.

Possessing a truly original and authentic story and set in a vibrant world, I keep coming back to this game for more.  A non-linear leveling system that actually lets the player customize the game around their own playstyle, and a Fate system that allows for either further customization and giving the player a sence of accomplishment.  I wish more RPGs could be as well thought out and beautiful as this one.

For a single playthrough to experience a near full clear will take well over 100 hours, and that does not even touch the DLC.  At $40, this is an RPG YOU HAVE TO TRY.  The demo includes not only the starter tutorial area"

reviewText:
Here's the tl;dr at the top of the post: Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning is absolutely worth your time.

Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning is an open-world, action RPG created by the unfortunately defunct 38 Strudios. After booting the game and playing the first extended mission, you will quickly realized that a lot of love went into this game. There's not many games out there that feel like the people who made them were making a game that they simply adored and would want to play themselves. However, this is, without a doubt, one of those rare games.



Let's take a look at some bullet points straight from the Steam store page:

- Uncover the secrets of Amalur in hundreds of hours of immersive gameplay, from the vibrant city of Rathir to the vast region of Dalentarth to the grim dungeons of the Brigand Hall Caverns.

This bullet is not exaggerating with the hundreds of hours" bit. I've easily sunk 63 hours (as of this posting) into the game and I have no idea if I'm close to the end. And you know what? I'm fine with that. The story is engaging and the world is full of awesome locations full of interesting people eager to send you even farther out into the world.

One of this game's most amazing strengths is that EVERY SINGLE QUEST has full voice acting. You never have to read a line of text if you don't want to. For me
date: this keeps the game interesting and pushes me to play farther into the story because I actually care about these characters. For once
recommended:
the NPCs are not just cardboard cutouts with text attached to their face. It's incredible what a difference that makes.



Okay so it has a ton of missions and voice acting
hoursPlayed: but does it have a world to support these characters and their stories? Hell yes it does! Take a look at this next point of interest:\n\n- Explore deep levels of lore in a universe steeped in 10
voteText: 000 years of fiction created by New York Times bestselling author R.A. Salvatore.\n\nKingdoms Of Amalur has an Elder Scrolls level of world back story. Every book you find has a story written inside them about the towns
helpfulPercent: cities
votesHelpful: people
votesTotal: and invading monsters. Exploration is rewarded with notes written by local townsfolk about their everyday lives
votesFunny: how they came to be
commentsCount: and their personal demons. Some merchants even keep inventory notes that you can peak at. You can spend hours just talking to individual people in the towns and learn how they feel about certain locations
column16: the legends of old
column17: and events that are likely to happen.\n\nIf you're one who craves lore

reviewText:
20 hours on record now and not disapointed. If you like a RPG game with a deep lore, love maximising your char (even overpowered maybe), then this is your game.

Pro:
-This game rewards you if you tend to stay and upgrade a bit (sidequest, explore/exploit game mechanics) before going to the next area. Doing some research in the fighting mechanics will pay off, same for searching for clues how to maximise your char early on.
-This game doesn't punish you for being intelligent and leaves the balance (and thus difficulty) in your hands.
-Decent graphics.
-Deep storyline. Troughout the world you get to know the lore even better with lorestones and sidequests.
-Upgrade your char. A lot. With good (but not game changing) upgrades.
-Change your character to another playstyle anytime you want. (This ability is very well integrated in the storyline: it is there for a reason. Thumbs up for the writers!)
-Fast travel.
-Many unique items. Item sets. All with unique abilities not found on equal 'normal' items.

Con:
-Content is repeated a lot. Especially the indoor environment build system is flawed.
-Combat is a bit thin. Just get a big mana regen or health regen and change weapons often. On the contrary, don't get that regen / upgrade and you experience a steep difficulty increase.
-Repeating sidequests. Fetch this, kill that.
-Crafting is there but no need for it. Just buy/find another better item.

reviewText:
Since I am bored at work And I'm tired of viewing screenshots from my friends, I decided to just review pretty much all the games I own ;D Yes... I am that bored...

Alright then, Kingdoms of Amalur:Reckoning is an RPG single player only, while you play you will get the feeling that since the world is so expansive, filled with life and Npc's it should have had an online mode or it should have been a FREE Online game.

To Describe this game in few words they would be: Immersive World, Quests, Magic, Fate, Medieval Style, Monsters and Hitting deers into space.

Ok, with that being sed you can picture what the game is like!

Let's start with the story, I was hyped about this game I remember seeing the trailers, how it had a guy who worked on the story of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, so the game showed great promise.

The game starts with the Story of the World, what's going on and HOW YOU DIED in the War the people of Amalur fought.
You wake up in a pile of decaying corpses and make your way up from underground to the Tower, you then realize that the tower is under attack by the Tuatha Dehon ( The bad guys) who are immortal.
As you go along you discover that you were revived by the well of souls and hence forth you are sent from quest to quest to find out what's going on.

The story telling in this game is average, the story itself is also average but the best by far in this game is the Combat System, fighting multiple units at once, with a fast paced system ranging from Bow, Hammer, Sword, Great Swords, Wands and the longer Wands XD. One of the best features in this game is The Fate power you get early on, which allows you to slow down Time and beat the crap out of your enemies and finish them off with an Epic and Awesome animations.

Since you died and were revived, you can now change your fate and that of those around you. Example: By killing the Monster X they will not have the children X they were supposed to have. That enables to player to change the world around him.

The Side quests are repetitive and meh, The Devs sed that to complete the game fully it would take about 300 hours. I object to that! I am 50 something hours in and and I have done every boring and repetitive side quest there is to do, and I'm almost done with it. :)

There are also interesting and vast Faction Quest Lines with alternate endings but in the End they just get repetitive as the side quests do.
I get the feeling that this game could have been more than what it was, too bad the company went broke from debt but there is still hope for the KOA Trade mark!!

Also a pretty huge part in this game is that, IT IS TOO EASY!! you'll realize this like 2-3 hours in, you destroy everything in your way pretty much without dying. I can even challenge myself into Not even dying once while playing through this entire game.
Thanks to the modding community there is a mod out there that makes the game harder to beat.

You can also craft armor, The skill system is quite vast, and there should have been Mounts in this game, I got tired of walking after a while.

And there you have it, my review for Kingdoms of Amalur:Reckoning if you are a person that loves RPG like I do you'll get over the fact that it's single player online and immerse yourself in the mythos like I did.

reviewText:
Bought this one on a whim when it went on sale and was positively surprised by it. Some might describe it as a poor man's Dark souls mixed with MMO-like open world game where you do side-quests and events while following the main plot. And the world is big, some might even call it huge, with lots of towns, dungeons and forgotten ruins to visit, there is also lots of backstory to the world and you get a feeling of being in a magical world that is undergoing a conflit between various factions of fae, men and possibly gods. You can also just kill stuff and take their loot if exploring the world and its multitude of personal stories isnt your cup of tea.

That brings up the combat which makes up a big part of the gameplay (i suggest gamepad over m/kb) or at least so far about the only gameplay ive encountered as this game is really puzzle-lite. Not that its a bad thing as the combat is smooth and enjoyable. There have been couple of challenging fights so far, nothing impossibly frustrating, but most of the encounters resemble one-sided beatdown much more than an grueling conflict of two equally matched forces. Changing your build and gear does bring variation to the game and after trying both the mage and warrior builds i ended up with plate-wielding warrioress using spells to support her combat capabilities.

Even with its faults and simplistic gameplay Kingdoms of Amalur is an enjoyable and fun experience for those times when you need to just sit back and relax. Get it but dont expect anything too deep or revolutionary from its gameplay even if its world had potential for future (shame the developer went bankrupt).

reviewText: This is a single player action RPG. (Kinda like Fable) Kingdoms of Amalur features five distinct regions and four playble races. Almain (Civilized Humans), the Dokkalfar (Dark Elves), the Ljosalfar (Light Elves), and the Varani (Nomadic Humans. The combat includes a 'Fate' system which allows the player to accumulate 'fate points' and enter Reckoning Mode. Which is a slow motion mode that allows you to quickly kill enemies and do brutal finishing moves. The world is very big and lots of side quest. No jumping which is kinda sad, (There is only predesignated spots to jump down from) but there is swimming and you can find some cool spots and side quests.  You have ability to buy homes and upgrade them (A lot like Fable) and you can communicate with , rob or kill NPCs. Which have their own consequences. In all this is a great Action RPG 9/10

reviewText:
Quick review after 40+ hours in the game (I play a lot offline, it doesn't count those usually).

First, for those of you wondering, this game plays without a hitch on an i5-3450 with a mere Intel HD 2500 gpu, on Windows 7-64 bit with 16 GB RAM at 1360x768 with no framerate slowdowns.  It probably will play on Intel laptops with at least an Intel HD 2500 gpu, that's impressive.

The combat is a lot like Darksiders or The Witcher 1.  Basically, you fight in a chain of attacks, usually moving in with each step in the chain.   There are abilities attached to each type of weapon.  You can fight with Daggers, Fae Daggers, Longsword, Chakram, Great Sword, Staff, Sceptre, Bow.   Each of these has a specialty tree where you learn additional passive and active abilities.   The active abilities have certain effects with certain special maneuvers learned.  So a Chakram attack can be held down with left click to create a large defensive spin area attack that applies the magic effect of the Chakram (burning, shock, etc) on everyone in the spin area.   It's quite simple to do and understand.

One of the beauties of this game is that every maneuver or ability you learn has a short movie in-game to examine, even before you learn it.  This gives you a good sense of the timing to achieve it and how it works.   A visual approach is used in almost everything.

And the visuals are impressive.  You have a long view  of the terrain before any level of details lower and if cautious can often see your unaware enemy before you must engage, allowing you to avoid many engagements.  (There are ambushes though, and some enemies are much more alert, so there is still inevitable excitement in any journey.)  The style is exactly as in the pictures and movies on the Store Page.   You can customize your character a fair amount, nose, eyes, gauntness, coloration, hair almost as much as in Skyrim.   The graphics are in the vein of Warcraft but higher resolution and more detailed.   The scenery is colorful.   The animations are very good, both in combat and not.

The Lore is at least as good as Skyrim.  But to be honest, Bethesda lore is always contradictory and confusing, books often are wrong or disagree with the game.  Amalur has lore also, it is less contradictory and confusing, but it is likewise not consistent with the actual game.  I don't think one should really depend on such Lore as meaningful in either set of games.  The difference is that here, the books tend to agree with the reality in the game.  In Skyrim or Oblivion, or even Morrowind, the Lore does not agree with all that is in the game.  About a third of it is totally wrong, and another third of it is inconsistent or just filler.   You'll find less of those inconsistencies in Amalur, but some exists and some is filler.

Combat is fluid, once learned it is easier than in Bethesda games.   Weapons apply much of the magic damage by the abilities and special moves, so there is a lot of value to loot and to armor.   Loot is easy to come by, one does not need to get the special help loot in one of the DLCs to do well, but the package deal is a good price.   I still have not even opened the DLC loot chest.   The most difficult level is level one, not because the in-game tutorial is hard, it is not, but because at each level you seem to grow stronger faster than the opposition.   Also, because it seems that the game's local monsters do not get stronger as you level, although that's a bit debateable.  They are at least capped in certain regions is my guess.

This means that although you are free to go almost anywhere, which is something sandbox RPG players like, you will find it tougher in the expected areas farther from your beginning and closer to the War's front.   You therefore get a sense of improving power as you level, as well as more flexibility in your skills.

I find the game fair at all difficulty levels, play as you wish, difficulty levels can be changed on the fly, so the game is very user friendly.

The dialog is spoken, and although there may not be quite as much dialog as in Skyrim or Oblivion, it's close to as much, well voiced, and more to the point.   I believe this is an area where the game shines.  Quests seem to make sense, even the side quests have value and of course they make you see all parts of the world while being done.  There are a ton of quests and all dialog whether in a quest or not is well done and germane to either the quest or adding flavor to the game world.

The music, the art, the graphics, the animation, the color palette, the characters, the combat, the quests, the open world, the gameplay, the voicework  -- all combine to give you a full, consistent, enjoyable experience.   It combines the feeling of a personal MMO done right with that of an RPG adventure done right, with good action, lots of story, player progression that matters, and so many ways to achieve things and interact with a world you will care about.

There is little to fault here.   Are you afraid of having too little money ... there are crates that spawn everywhere, they aren't chests but remind one of the common loot crates on the Docks of Oblivion's ports.  Break them and you will get some coins over time.  So money is not an issue, although this is not the best way to make money.   Common enemies will respawn in the wild, perhaps even invading a town from time to time.   The guards will respond, but they can take their time, if you kill these interlopers you get a chance for more loot.  Things like this calm you in feeling you can make progress if you fall behind and that there is safety in familiar places you befriend.   Yet, there are ambushes regularly triggered, making good sense in the game, causing either rebel thiefs or beasts to challenge you in various locations as you simply travel about.  This adds to immersion.  There are many special hidden chests, some not so hidden that you can't find them if you look in every tree trunk or every path off the main beat.   But also there are some skills you can acquire to make your mini-map and map help you find more seriously hidden items that you might not find at all otherwise, even secret doors or secreted areas.  Every skill tree has value and you are not limited to any one class or tree or weapon specialization.  Whether you wish to be a better merchant or find hidden areas as a Thief, or cast many spells as a Mage, or fight as a skilled Warrior, you can always mix and match as well. Reset your skills for a price in gold, re-imagining your character.  If you like, craft potions, enhance weapons, salvage anything.

This is a great game, frequently 75% off, so you will not be disappointed.   I can't speak to whether or not the game is too hard or too easy, I would say it after some adjustment is probably easier than the Elder Scrolls series, but that doesn't make the journey any less enjoyable.   So if you want to travel in a beautiful story world with lots to do, in a more colorful and cartoony world that still has all the detail in graphics and story that you ache for, this is a game to recommend highly to you.

Enjoy.  It is often on sale at 75 % off.   Buy it then.  The complete pack is usually $10 and the main game alone is $5.  It's a shame, these developers deserved a chance to make many more games, they would have been equal to the best.   This game has so many extra features done flawlessly, like the map and the movie clips for skill moves, that one has to wonder how this company ever went broke.   A great shame.

NOTE:  This game does seem to require an EA account, but it's easy to register and works flawlessly otherwise.   For me it checks in via internet with the EA servers for authentication every time it starts up.  It may be possible to play the game without this internet access, but I mention this as information.

reviewText:
This is an ok game not amazing but not too bad either. For starters this is made by EA and you need to always be online to play which is a pain.

Story:
The story is ok but very bland and not really interesting lots of stuff to do and places to go but very predictable and I pretty much knew what was going to happen to the end.

Content:
Tons of quests (I MEAN TONS)to do hundreds of hours of content but also many are the same and are not interesting I never really wanted to do any side quests because they were boring and just a pain. Also lots of enemy type but very overused in many areas. I personally had a problem with WOLF's are the ♥♥♥♥ing worst and a the biggest pain in the ♥♥♥ ever. Lots of cool places and seemed very inspirational and just cool too look at even if the game isn't the most graphical intensive game.

Graphics(How it runs):
This game is not the most graphical intensive game ever and it is not hard to run and could be played on almost any PC. I have never crashed or had any game breaking glitches. There are some settings and you can rebind all keys. Plays well on keyboard and mouse.

Combat:
Combat is the main point of this game or well the best part. I had fun fighting bosses and finishing them off was fun and satisfying as hell.

Misc:
-Inventory is well done and you can put items in the junk section to easily sell if uneeded.
-Camera is pretty bad and a pain in the ♥♥♥ to control.
-Fateshifts are very fun and i loved finishing off bosses.
-I was a Mage with my first play through and many items need you to add points to a warrior and I found this to be a pain and many good items unusable.
-Level up system is well done and you can put points into any class.
-Voice acting on everyone and is ok but the main character which seems off to me.

Its an ok game and I plan to play through the game again this time taking my time with it as a Warrior After I am done with this play through.

Final Verdict:
7/10 It's ok

reviewText:
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning succeeds in some important ways, but in my opinion inevitably falls flat on its face for anyone who has played RPGs before. It really depends on why you play RPGs.

KoA has a story that is at times refreshing and inspired, like with almost everything surrounding the Fae and their interactions with your character.  At other times, it is cliche and groan-inducing; just about anything having to do with the Fate" concept in the game was at best predictable and at worst actually insulting in its lameness. The dialogue outside of story missions was also trite and felt written around a quest that had already been programmed into the game without a justification. This is extra egregious in a game that advertises how a famous fantasy author developed the story.

It has an art style that screams in vivid colors and exaggerated animations

reviewText: In my personal view, Kingsdoms of Amalur: Reckoning has been the best Fantasy RPG I have played so far, even 3 years after it's release. This work deserves more. This world has been created with great detail and amazing imagination, the story is classic fantasy yet totally different. And the combat speed and effects will burn your eyes out! I always return to Amalur, exploring the vast landscapes is a treat in its own right and there are still so many missions and quests yet to master.

reviewText:
It's a damn shame 38 studios isn't a thing anymore tl;dr Hack&Slash RPG that is 100% worth your money if you want a time sink and a decent story set in a visually outstanding world.


Stumbled upon this gem a while back. Fantastic time sink for anyone looking to lose hours of their day in a sytlistically dissimilar game.

It's a Hack&Slash RPG. This means that for those who like to fawn over the mechanics of combat in other RPGs, you may find some issues with this game. After a few hours, repitition does rear its' head if you only tend to play one type of the 3 main RPG classes (Spells and pointy hat, quick with a small stick and slow with a big stick).

That being said, the game rewards you immensely for spending skill points in all of the 3 main skill trees and usingthe varied types of weapons. Some of the attacks you can pull off with well timed spells after ranged/melee combos are simply outstanding.

Story doesn't usually rank highly on my list of things I think NEED to be good for a game to be good but it certainly helps, especially in an RPG. The main quest in Reckoning will send you all over the place in stages, typical to any modern fantasy title. It takes you on a monumental adventure, eventually taking on an enemy no one had a damn clue existed and saving the day etc. good stuff all around.

It's in my personal opinion that ending was a bit weak and that it lets down the story as a whole. Rather than bundle up everything, it sort of hangs loose. This may have been due to a desire to create a sequel.

Nitpicking for those super into game mechanics i.e. CONS GO HERE
The world itself looks outstanding, however the only real issue I had with this entire game was the lack of ANY major verticality. The world is by no means planar, but the only transition between up, middle and down was if you interacted with the world to perform a jump into a roll landing from up above OR the world slopes down/up to meet the next area.
Even if the height difference is an inch, you can't simply step up to that height.

While released in 2012, the game has aged fairly well. Would absolutely recommend if it comes up in your Summer Steam sale or a normal purchase if you're simply looking for a solid game.

reviewText:
I'm not much of one for writing reviews; I don't do it often, and have no practice at it. But, what I can say here, is that for years I've been looking for a game that's centered primarily, if not wholly, around Celtic mythology, rather than generic European medieval fantasy or feudal Asian mythology. This game delivered, moreso than I could have ever thought a game could. Why there haven't been more games featuring such strong Celtic themes is beyond me, but Kingdoms of Amalur: Recokoning showed that it can be done, and done very well. I was definitely impressed with the story of the game.

As far as gameplay, things were pretty good. Combat and controls felt better with a gamepad than mouse and keyboard, but that's never been a dealbreaker for me. I feel there could have been more done with combos and chaining attacks, because combat felt a little static after awhile, but it wasn't awful. Most quests(but not all; here's looking at you, Til's Collection) were interesting and often felt like an interesting task, rather than a chore to do for XP. The main quest line especially was fun, interesting, and kept me pulled in to the game. Factions you could join in the game I felt were pretty mediocre, and are your generic warriors, mages, and rogues factions. Their quests were fun, but I never really felt like my character truely belonged to the faction upon joining. The one major downside I felt in the game was gear drops. Almost always, what you can craft at each level was better than anything you could find, even rare named pieces or sets. As for the DLC, Teeth of Narros had a fun main story line, but for the most part it felt drawn out and monotonous. The side quests were pretty boring, and involved a lot of backtracking. Legend of Dead Kell was much better, and felt more involved.

One more note: This game is LONG. And I really mean long, especially if you are a completionist and want to do all of the side quests.

reviewText: Baby's first Dark Souls?  Illegitimate spawn of World of Warcraft and Fable?  No, it's AMALUR!  As generic arpgs go, this one isn't terrible.  And while the combat is fun, without trainers/hacks it presents absolutely no challenge to anyone with hand eye coordination greater than a three-toed sloth.  The world is huge.  Ridiculously so.  You have to skip around 40% of the content if you don't want to overlevel and make an already pitiful difficulty curve that much more trivial.  Far too much time and resources went into creating real estate versus actually putting it to good: most of the quests/writing is below MMO level, almost all of the non-combat skills are utterly worthless, and balancing is non-existant.  Left to their own devices, Big Huge Games might have made this a great game.  We have Curt Schilling to thank for turning their hard work into a hot mess.

reviewText: This is one of my favorite OTS (Over-The-Shoulder) RPG games to date.  The combat is simple yet fun and graphical.  These games are so few and hard to find.  Too bad there isnt a sequal.  I played through it as a sorcerer/rogue because I love the chakrams.  The downfall of the game was that you pretty much max the power of your gear way before the ending of the game.  I probably wasted more time grinding for loot to deconstruct and re-forge because i kept wanting to find the best gear....but in the end it was still fun.  Most would probably complain that it was too easy but i found it refreshing to be able to move forward than to die and try again over and over.  I definately recommend to action rpg fans.  This is a keeper game....meaning its one to play again after so much time has passed, so might as well keep it around.

reviewText: KoA is going to be remembered not for the game, but for the complete collapse of the studio and the fallout from that. Which is a shame, because KoA is a decent game. Right away I'd like to point out, it's essentially Fable + MMO, all single player. Combat is generally quick and easy, quests are your standard fetch and kill fare, and the world is generic high fantasy. That said, it's also lovingly crafted and just flat out fun to play. Even on the hardest setting the game is easy, and as quick as I am to decry games being dumbed down, it can be incredibly satisfying at times to just tear through hordes of enemies. The skill system has some decent depth to it, as does the gear. The world is beautiful and the sound design is solid. The game can feel grindy, again, it's basically a single player MMO, but it's also fun if you're into that sort of thing. If nothing else, pick it up cheap for some awesome chakram action.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game. This company. Oh the potential. RA Salvatore created a wonderful world. The developers did a good job of making it feel large and alive. But all of the money issues... they are gone now. We will never see a KoA Online.

Let me start with the bad. The difficulty? Too easy. The DLC was letting players pay to effetively add power (at least the preorder DLC I had). I never understand why players want to effectively pay money to use cheat codes. And how developers started deciding that that would even work. But it is common now. The story? Mediocre... oh the world is wonderful but the story... well it is not quite top tier.

The good. The combat is fun. The character customization feels nice. The world (yeah I keep saying that). It could have made a great MMO but we will never know.

The devs just spent too much money, took on too much debt. I still recommend this game when you see it go on sale. But just remember that the team is gone. Don't expect an expansion, more DLC, or even more patches. I feel that $30 is a bit steep but at half off I can definitely say give it a try.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This was a very enjoyable game for me. From start to finish the backgrounds are visually stunning and each different hub area really looks different and visually sets the tone of the game. The fighting is fluid and responsive, in which you really feel like you are a powerful warrior. The fighting animations look fantastic and vary well with different weapons. There is a lot of lore to discover, some of which is interesting. The questing can get a little laborious at times. The loot drops are not that great. I made a good pair of charkrams early on and never really found a better weapon. With that there is a pretty good crafting and gemcraft mechanic in the game that allows you to make comparable items to those drops found on mobs. By the end the story sort of fell off and seemed a little rushed. The side quests can be interesting at times and the NPC are for the most part interesting and engageing. My biggest complaint would have to be that the game is very very easy.\nIn the end this a good open world action rpg that shouldn't disappoint!

reviewText: I fell in love with this game at first sight, I saw that it would be like one of the older RPGs, except it had its own ring to it- it isn't some sort of hack and slash or ping into random places sort of game, its a game that once your in, your mind is the key to your role, specifically, you have the power to chose exactly how you're going to play you're part of the game, whether it be a classic staff & spell, sword & shield, or dagger & bow, the game does not force your class on you, instead, you may be a hammer wielding thief or a chakram throwing warlord. The leveling tree in this game is spectacular, you level up, choose what attribute you want to level up, and then ability points that allow you way to carnage wreaking moves that can turn the tide of war. reviewText:
Well, this is an odd game to review as its often mistaken for what it is. It isn't Skyrim, at all. A game it is much closer to is Fable. I liked Fable, it's not the most in depth RPG but its fun and the combat is nice. Now, back to Kingdoms. The story line is a typical RPG story, you are seemingly a nobody, but something “happens” and you are now the key to everything. I don't want to spoil the game as the story is nice, but its nothing fancy. Serviceable with a hint of charm is how I would describe it. If you do not like the story, the game is built so you can skip that on and get to the combat. The combat is similar to Fable in how it works, but its much more advanced. You have the typical class choices, a big warrior, stealthy dual blades, wizard. They do differ a lot, and how you build them is up to you, although it doesn't offer THAT much of a choice that you would consider it important for multiplay through other than each class on its own.

The inventory system is not great, but it works fine enough if it is a little cumbersome. Plenty of lot to play about with, and a lot of side quests and mini-stories that do a good job of introducing you to the other elements of the game. I would happily say this game is a good weekend game, you would be hard pressed to dislike it too much. It is not as free as Skyrim and I think some people looking for that type of RPG fix might get a little put off with this game, but if you have ever enjoyed Fable you would do well to give this a shot.

Presentation is nice, it doesn't feel like a cheap game, it feels very well built and everything is built with a purpose. Its a genuinely nice game to play.

reviewText:
Not a great rpg but also not a bad one. Runs smoother than any game I've ever owned and the combat is fun but the game does quickly get very repetitive. I would play it more but it just got so old and boring I couldn't stand to finish it. It is hard to pinpoint why it is so boring, it just is. Probably mainly because of the combat getting old fast.
The baseball player Curt Schilling who I saw play quite often when I was younger financed the company that made this game and this was the only game they made. They ended up going bankrupt and shutting down after not being able to pay back loans to the state of Rhode Island.
Game has good graphics which along with combat are its high points. I would not exactly say the graphics are great because they are not, and are not bad either, just colorful and pretty. Weapons are cool and the spells/skills look great, however few skills there are, and enemies are varied and cool also. For sure worth a look if you want a decent RPG. If you want crack, heroin, and a BJ/HJ combo, talk to Josh Holmes' sister. She has spent more time on her back than a mattress salesman with alcoholism and narcolepsy.

6.5/10

reviewText:
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a action rpg with some slight problems. In general the user controls are good and feel intuitive, the quest tracker is undertsandable and guides you to the wanted place with high accuracy, for some this might not be the most wanted quality but for game as large as KoA:R quest tracker is mandatory. Combat systems are explained clearly and as games greatest asset, you can build your character pretty freely to suit your personal tastes.

Even with the good and working character building, the game has some major flaws. The problems start at midgame and continue from there. The problem at least for me lies at both game content and at actual combat system. As for game content the problem is mainly about:

- Mediocerly written plot and character interactions, you will not care about the dialogue after a while and certanly you will not be able to remember the names of the NPC:s in the game, at least I didn't.
- Encounters are about all identical, you will not give much of a thought for the cave/mountain/primire troll which you encounter for the 50th time in single playthrough same with about every encounter in the game, after about level 7 you have necountered 90% of the games enemy types and rest of the game rotates those.

For comabt system the major problems are:

- Severly broken combat, it is far too easy. You don't often get any feeling from the combat, as above you will be fighting the same troll with 80% same skills and animations.
-Too effective potions: 1) potions take next to zero inventory space 2) at second highest ~level 28 the startter potion heals for 70% and you can spam them at insane ratio (one about per 5 seconds) 3) the aftermentoined potion at that any level after 5th has effective cost on null.
-Unscaling abilities the abilites at start feel too broken but after level 20 you will do 10x the damage with your auto attack and all reasonalbe abilites seem passive or active percentual buffs to damage.
-Too effective bloking with warrior destinies you at endgame became able to block anything in the game makeing the comabt bit cheesy since you just plot the block up and laugh since not even the troll is able to penetrate your defences.
-----OBNOXIOUS COMABT: The comabt is sometimes a bloody chore, when you are fighting the same enemies with just 10 x the normal hp you get slightly agitated, and usually the dificulty come from annoyance and not from difficult fight, in the entire game i encountered a single fight which was actually hard.


In overall the game is fine purchace from sale. At full price it's slightly at the expencive if compring the complexity of the content to the price tag, but at decent sale, do buy the game. It has fluid mechaning built around staggering your enemies to death and it's fun and easy to get into. At the endgame developers could have made more unque content to make the game more enjoyable, but regardless it's not the worst purchese you could make.

reviewText:
This is a very good game, with a lot of options. In fact, it's so big and deep that the game becomes overwhelming. It also gets repetitive very fast. Fighting enemies gets dull. You have a plethora of moves you can unlock as you level, but in the end, a short 3 hit combo, block hit and dodge are all you need to survive. Weapons like bows or two handed weapons become redundant once you can craft your own items with god tier gems. Daggers, with their speed are the only choice as all the enhancements are +X per hit, instead of scaled or % increases.

Don't get me wrong, I LOVE this game and go back to it every so often. With an art design between Fable and WoW and a combat system reminiscent of Devil May Cry (minus the focus on strung out combos) it is incredibly fun for short bursts. The Combat is fun and takes a while to reach the repetitive droning that I stated earlier. There is a large variety of spells and skills, but weapons and armor are pretty much able to be maxed out just around halfway through the game.

Note if you want a challenge, top tier regen gems and life/mana leech gems on weapons should be avoided. The only downside here is the lack of variety for enemies. Most enemies are beefed up/palette swapped versions of enemies you encounter early on.

The world is huge, and the lore is pretty deep if you take the time to find it all. The Lorestones are impressive in their stories, and the bonuses they provide are generally useful. But there are TONS of Lorestones. Trying to find them all is tedious even after getting the upgrade that reveals EVERYTHING on the map. Which leads me to the last point: the Jack of all trades approach is not only good, but generally preferred in this game. The rewards at high levels in this game (where your classes are determined by which one you want to be and qualify for) are far above the high level rewards for any other classes, IMO.


This game is a good play, but due to some repetitive (if fun) combat and quests, it only gets a solid 7 of 10 from me. You should play it, especially if it's cheap. But don't get obsessed with 100% completion.

reviewText:
Picked this one up on sale back in June for $10 (game + all DLC). If you're looking for blockbuster material, you won't find it here.

The story is excellent and the lore to back it up equally great. So if story driven stuff is what you're after, you should enjoy this. For me, it was the sole reason I went ahead with playing it to completion.

The main problem is the graphics and gameplay drag it down badly. I've been talking about it in passing as though it was a 2006 release because frankly it doesn't look as nice as Oblivion, then just noticed it has a 2012 date on it. OK.

Gameplay is very very MMO-ey, and as it turns out there's a reason for that. It was supposed to be one at one point but got downscaled into a single player game. So yo have lots and lots of combat action and loot grinding going on.

The two DLCs were actually much better than the main game too, though that could be because I'm partial to content that gives me castles and keeps to build and upgrade :P

Over all, worth it when it's on sale. I'd not pay the full $40 for the whole collection though.

reviewText:
After reading through several positive reviews of Kingdoms of Amalur, I bought Kingdoms with relatively high hopes for the game. Admittedly, when the opening sentence of a game's description name-drops RA Salvatore and Todd McFarlane as the creative minds behind it, I probably should have set my expectations a bit lower, but we were all young and foolish once, right? Overall, Kingdoms presents a game that's not entirely without it's good points, but those elements are buried underneath the larger, sweeping design decisions dragging this game down.

At it's core, the main problem is one of level design. While the game world is large, there's not really much there. The towns are small, sparsely populated, and serve as little more than housing for a population of layabouts looking for some adventurer to do their  pointless errands  quests. The countryside is big and empty except for the regular enemy spawn points and dungeons are much the same. Really, the entire game world seems designed much more for a MMO than it does for a single player game, where the gameplay is really meant to serve as a backdrop for player interaction and competition. As the player adventures out into the game's wilderness alone, however, it's vast emptiness of any meaningful content quickly becomes apparent.

Similarly, the writing, at best, is passable, but I never really get the sense that my character is anything more than a mass of stats and that the majority of the NPCs in the game are anything more than quest nodes with some dialogue attached. It doesn't help that nothing you do in the game seems to actually matter. Take the evil route in a quest and slaughter an entire village? Well... it gets you the assurance that... at some point in the future... the place will become really terrible, but there's never a noticeable change to the world or the way NPCs perceive you beyond that.

While, as others have pointed out, the combat is well-designed, I can't really say that it's much of an upside in the game. The problem remains that, because of the lackluster level design, the combat never really gets the chance to shine like it could. Enemies spawn in random groups across the game's empty countryside and dungeons, leading to the player being confronted with a long stream of samey and increasingly tedious battles.

Kingdoms suffers from a design ethic of bigness" and "more content." While the world is certainly big
date: this bigness seems only to weigh the game down. In the end
recommended: I couldn't help but wonder if Kingdoms would have benefitted from offering the player a smaller
hoursPlayed: more carefully designed experience."
voteText: February 2, 2014

To be honest, this game is bad, despite good combat system and tons of content. It's just failing to hold you to play. It's okay in short bursts. It's a pretty nice action rpg, but killing thousands and thousands of same enemies (which can take a lot of time, esp near the end, because game just throwing dozens of tuatha elite troops, and trolls at you)
Combat system has it's own flaws too. It becomes repetitive as heck after a while, because you usually stick to two weapons, which suits you (in my case - chakrams and greatsword). It's still entertaining to watch, but if there a lot of enemies there is a great chance that character will be stunlocked.
Quests are pretty bore too. It's either fetch-quests or kill quests, with very very rare puzzles. And tasks - WoW dailies. Bring me ten bear legs to get a bag of gold. Rince and repeat.
Factions - kinda good. Travelers and warsworn are pretty good, nothing original, but still pretty good. Backstabbing, heroic deeds all that kind of stuff. Kinda wish there were more epic fight and moments like in main story. Houses of ballads and sorrows, and mage's guild - good story, but notthing incredible. I even can't decide whether i want to be the bad guy or the good guy.
Overall i would call this game average at most. Some good ideas, decent fighting system, tons of not so interesting content, but extremely repetitive.

reviewText: Baby's first Dark Souls?  Illegitimate spawn of World of Warcraft and Fable?  No, it's AMALUR!  As generic arpgs go, this one isn't terrible.  And while the combat is fun, without trainers/hacks it presents absolutely no challenge to anyone with hand eye coordination greater than a three-toed sloth.  The world is huge.  Ridiculously so.  You have to skip around 40% of the content if you don't want to overlevel and make an already pitiful difficulty curve that much more trivial.  Far too much time and resources went into creating real estate versus actually putting it to good: most of the quests/writing is below MMO level, almost all of the non-combat skills are utterly worthless, and balancing is non-existant.  Left to their own devices, Big Huge Games might have made this a great game.  We have Curt Schilling to thank for turning their hard work into a hot mess.

reviewText:
Love this game. It does have it's slow moments due to the fact it was built upon the remnants of the MMORPG the game was originally supposed to be so there are lots of mmo type quests and a vast world with about 30 or so areas.

Talent trees while generic are well thought out. and are supplemented by gate cards which allow your character to specialize into a class based on how many points you have spent in each of the 3 trees. ( Might, Finess, Sorcery)

These cards even come fully stocked with hybrid classes for people like me who like to mix and match for interesting character set ups.  Each class can add some itneresting features as you slowly upgrade with more points.

An example would be once you have enough sorcery in the rpimary and hybrid sorc classes your dodge can become a short teleport instead of a roll.


I highly recommend this game expecially if it is on sale.

reviewText: This game has to be my all time favorite. It has a vast and wonderous world to explore, and and an entire worlds worth of in game lore to explore made by reknowned author R.A. Salvatore. There are tons of things to do, so many quests to complete. Also it has a coveted aggression mode to toggle on. So. Remember that town that you were mad at. Wipe it of the map. Or not. I don't judge. The combat system is very good so it has a very gratifying feel to it, and is well 1v1 or 1 vs an army of trolls (but decidely harder then -_-). The DLC adds so much to do as well so I would highly recommend getting it as well. It also has a beautiful musical score.\n\n11/10 would unsuccessfully woo blue elf that stalks you throughout the game

reviewText:
Amalur is a well-polished game with it's base game being extensive, easily offering up 40+ hours of gameplay and up to 70+ if you explore all side quests. Its colourful, with well scripted dialogue, some unique combinations of standard fantasy concepts without being too aggressively unique, and placed an interesting spin on the undying character (with an idea as interesting as Assassin's Creed's Animus). However it fails to maintain interest during the late game as quests and challenges become all too easy, leading up to a disappointing ending that would have been far more interesting if it had more impetus.
Boss fights are also poorly executed with a variety of standard RPG tactics being utilised, and no unique inventive ways to challenge the enemies provided. Many of the Bosses attacks, have been done in previous games before, not a problem if you're new to the genre, I suppose, but problematic for 3rd person action RPG veterans.
Amalur does provide an interesting levelling and skills tree progression, that allows for limited customisability, but does shine in its simplicity to understand, and ways to play around and discover effective combinations of skills from its three separate progressions.
It's most definitely a fun game to play and waste a few days on, but won't offer much depth either in combat or narrative, so will always be a rather dismal second to its far more developed and innovative competitors.

reviewText: Id like to go on record as saying that I am a picky MO FO when it comes to RPs... That said... This is one fo the best RPGs I have played in the last 20 years, graphics not withstanding. It is masively expansive, every time I thought the game was over it just kept rolling out more story and all of the stories hold their own then come together to form an even larger story! I have spent many hours just getting to lvl 20 and I feel like I have been through wave after wave of build up then grind. I love the look of it as well as the support characters (some of who make me want to slap the poo out of them, others make me want to take them behind closed doors...), I give this game a 9.5/10 It loses .5 points because the merchant buy/sell menu makes you wade through ALL of your gear to sell a few things that you dont want (Including the crafting gear which if you are a collecter can be MASSIVE). The merchant menu should be more like the menu in your houses storage box, now that would be superb! A must buy for any real RPer out there! And dont forget the DLC!

reviewText:
This is a very good game, with a lot of options. In fact, it's so big and deep that the game becomes overwhelming. It also gets repetitive very fast. Fighting enemies gets dull. You have a plethora of moves you can unlock as you level, but in the end, a short 3 hit combo, block hit and dodge are all you need to survive. Weapons like bows or two handed weapons become redundant once you can craft your own items with god tier gems. Daggers, with their speed are the only choice as all the enhancements are +X per hit, instead of scaled or % increases.

Don't get me wrong, I LOVE this game and go back to it every so often. With an art design between Fable and WoW and a combat system reminiscent of Devil May Cry (minus the focus on strung out combos) it is incredibly fun for short bursts. The Combat is fun and takes a while to reach the repetitive droning that I stated earlier. There is a large variety of spells and skills, but weapons and armor are pretty much able to be maxed out just around halfway through the game.

Note if you want a challenge, top tier regen gems and life/mana leech gems on weapons should be avoided. The only downside here is the lack of variety for enemies. Most enemies are beefed up/palette swapped versions of enemies you encounter early on.

The world is huge, and the lore is pretty deep if you take the time to find it all. The Lorestones are impressive in their stories, and the bonuses they provide are generally useful. But there are TONS of Lorestones. Trying to find them all is tedious even after getting the upgrade that reveals EVERYTHING on the map. Which leads me to the last point: the Jack of all trades approach is not only good, but generally preferred in this game. The rewards at high levels in this game (where your classes are determined by which one you want to be and qualify for) are far above the high level rewards for any other classes, IMO.


This game is a good play, but due to some repetitive (if fun) combat and quests, it only gets a solid 7 of 10 from me. You should play it, especially if it's cheap. But don't get obsessed with 100% completion.

reviewText:
Picked this one up on sale back in June for $10 (game + all DLC). If you're looking for blockbuster material, you won't find it here.

The story is excellent and the lore to back it up equally great. So if story driven stuff is what you're after, you should enjoy this. For me, it was the sole reason I went ahead with playing it to completion.

The main problem is the graphics and gameplay drag it down badly. I've been talking about it in passing as though it was a 2006 release because frankly it doesn't look as nice as Oblivion, then just noticed it has a 2012 date on it. OK.

Gameplay is very very MMO-ey, and as it turns out there's a reason for that. It was supposed to be one at one point but got downscaled into a single player game. So yo have lots and lots of combat action and loot grinding going on.

The two DLCs were actually much better than the main game too, though that could be because I'm partial to content that gives me castles and keeps to build and upgrade :P

Over all, worth it when it's on sale. I'd not pay the full $40 for the whole collection though.
